description:
Super burrito is my go to if I'm too hungry to last the train ride some. Staff is always friendly. Sometimes I get free chops, sometimes I have to pay ‍

Place is clean, and has several tvs playing various games.
author: Alex G.

description:
Good god this place is horrible. I came in here to munch on something before going to the CalTrain - bad decision. Later that night, I had a bad stomach ache. Not sure if it was this place, but I wouldn't be surprised 

Fish tacos tasted so bad, and bland.
Yea, not really much else to say.
author: Jason J.

description:
If you care about your health, fear ecoli, and hepatitis B, don't risk your health by dining at Iron Cactus.

I'll start off with the obvious. This isn't a legit taqueria. This ain't no Mission burrito. This is a sorry excuse for Mexican, and a serious threat to your health.

I'm about to break it down:

Red salsa is greasy, green salsa needs avocado and more spice. Slow down, I'm 100% Mexican, which gives me license to drop these truth bombs. I'll continue. Employees have an attitude. They look annoyed, as if you're doing them a favor by eating there. There's a blonde gentleman that usually takes the orders, and he's guaranteed to mix things up. Have them repeat your order. Twice. If he's not there, that place isn't run professionally. Case and point, my visit with my toddler, on 5/31/18. We drop in about 1:30p. I order for both my daughter and myself. The gentleman that brings our food has a glove on only one hand, which I immediately find strange,  as he's carrying another dish in his un-gloved hand. He drops our entrees off, then proceeds to bus all of the dirty tables, followed by him entering the food preparation area and picking up more entrees for guests. Still with the same dirty glove on. He drops them off at their respective tables. With the same dirty-ass glove on. I mention this to the lady at the cash register, who appears to also be filling the manager role. I tell her it's not a safe practice and he needs to remove his one glove and wash his hands after bussing dirty tables, before picking up guests' food. She agrees to talk to him. She does, then he removes his dirty glove and happily prepares his own lunch at the food preparation area-without washing his hands prior to doing so. If I needed a sign that none of my message had landed with the manager, it came quickly. She takes a new client's order, rings him up, heads straight to the food preparation area without washing her hands, grabs a tortilla and throws it on the grill, patting the tortilla several times, heads to the dining area to bus tables (as ALL of the employees are taking their lunch (this never happens when the gentleman I mention above is acting as the manager), buses tables, heads jack to the food preparation area without washing her hands after handling two tables-worth of dirty dishes, and continues to grab the tortilla off the grill with her bare hands and hands the dude his hepatitis A burrito. WT-----! Seriously, no concept of cleanliness, sanitation, germ and disease transmission! 

They wear a glove in one hand to give the impression that they understand cleanliness and disease transmission prevention. The above clearly paints a very different picture. I. Rest. My. Case. And for the record, I'm a nurse. I know a little something about disease transmission/prevention.
author: Gabriela W.

description: Absolutely love their happy hour....$3 coronas and $1 delicious tacos. Quick, affordable and yummy.
author: Courtney E.

description:
I'm surprised this place has a low star rating. For the area, it's not bad. It's not the most authentic, but it's pretty flavorful. 

I tried the spicy shrimp salad and it was yummy! Must get it with the cilantro dressing. Service was fast and the lady who served our table was nice.
author: Jerrica N.

description:
The Iron Cactus has very limited options, but it does the trick. 

We got some beer and red wine and hung out for a bit. Prices were reasonable, and the best part was the seating; we snagged two bar stools by the window, and it was awesome during sunset - even with all the construction going on.
author: Nic Z.

description: Decent burrito, all flavors just right, not greasy or dry all. (I asked for spicy, and was surprised it wasn't all that spicy. Maybe they blandify for the game-goers and gentrifiers.) Pretty decent menu, too, all the usual meat and bean choices, etc. Seemed pretty close to an authentic SF taqueria.
author: Charles B.

description:
Great place for Taco Tuesday ( $1 dollar per street Taco). 
They always bring the food pretty fast and have drink specials.

2 vegetarian options for the tacos: vegetables and/or Tofu.

It's a great place to have a drink and some food after work or before going to a game at the Ballpark.
author: Elena C.

description: I can't explain the low raining for the Iron Cactus, but it contradicts all my experiences of  eating there. While I only stop there for their dollar tacos, I've always had a great time talking to the workers and just taking a pit stop. Their Al Pastor is my favorite and for the price of their taco specials, you can't complain.
author: Etc C.

description: This place is super close to where I work and I've walked by it multiple times. The super quesadilla here is the best. Fast and friendly service !
author: Georgiy R.

description:
Even for $1 Taco Tuesday, I have regrets. Yuck yuck yuck. The meat looked like they've been sitting there forever. Some are shriveled, others are just sitting in unflavored drippings. 

Nice space but food does not make up for it.
author: Cindy W.

description: I like their nachos and burritos, and restaurant's inside is cozy. However, don't go there when AT & T Park has a big event. At that time, this restaurant is so crowded!! One additional information, their WiFi is good!!
author: Yumiko H.

description:
Really cool taqueria in SOMA near the ball park.
They have 12 beers here. Some on tap. 
Happy hour from 3-6 mon-Friday. 
The super burrito wet style with green sauce is delicious.
There is a cafe that is connected to the taqueria.
Outside patio seating.
Would recommend coming here before a giants game. It's walking distance to the ballpark.
author: Kevin S.

description:
Amazing Happy Hour deals -- $1/taco and $3/beer just can't be beat. You can get every flavor they have plus a drink to wash it down for $10 + tax!

Outside of happy hour, I've had a regular burrito once and while it was decent, it was not a great value compared to the above.

Still, I'll come here again whenever I'm in the area.
author: Ian H.

description:
Easily the worst tacos I have ever had in my entire life. 

Meat tasted like it was bad, funky. Nervous about 12 hours from now.
author: Stephen D.

description: I'm not sure why people are hating on this place with so many low stars. Was it the best, most authentic Mexican food? No, hence only giving it 4 stars. However, it was solid and very tasty. The staff were nice, the place was clean, lots of good food options, they had a decent selection of beers on tap to choose from... I'd eat here again. So if you're waiting for a train or game, or are just in the area, pretty solid eats for this part of town.
author: Faith M.

description: I had a great experience.  The food was decent, the prices are affordable, the atmosphere is great, and the service was exceptional. They were very busy when I walked in and the line moved surprisingly fast.   When my food came I started eating it and noticed that one of my tacos, was missing sour cream, cheese , and guacamole (I ordered a super taco and got a standard one).  People make mistakes especially when they're working fast.  So I understand that.  What makes this place exceptional is how they handle it.  When I saw someone and asked to get it fixed he took care of it right away.  He took my order back in the kitchen and brought a completely fresh plate immediately.  It was nice to feel handled and see that they were happy to take care of it without question.
author: Jodi D.

description:
Pros
-Very friendly staff
-Salsas had good flavor and heat 
-$3 beer during happy hour
-Pleasant outdoor seating

Cons
-Burrito was bland. 

I'm new to the area and decided to stop in. The place was very clean and I got my void very quick. I ordered an al pastor super burrito. There was too much sour cream- it dominated the burrito and could barely taste the other ingredients. It all kind of blended together. But the place was spacious, clean, and they had some good beers on draft. I won't go back if I am just looking for something to eat but would happily go back to drink and hang out.
author: Michael C.

description: I decided to stop by here before catching the Caltrain as it was close by and seemed lively. The service was good but I was a bit disappointed with the food. I ordered a veggie burrito with mild salsa and a green melon juice. The juice and the chips that came along with it were quite tasty; however, I found the burrito to be somewhat bland. Perhaps it would be better with spicy salsa? It was quite filling though. I think I would only come back if it was my last option...
author: Carol M.

description: This place is alright and a good value portion wise. Definitely not the most authentic. Kind of similar to Chevy's actually. Well, better than that! But not extraordinarily so. But put enough salsa and hey... it's Monday's lunch ok?
author: Dante J.

description: Tofu is dope, salsa is on point. Good place for a vegetarian bite. 5 stars for how good the salsa was alone.
author: Jeasica C.

description:
For what it lacks with its unremarkable Mexican fare, The Iron Cactus makes up for with a decent beer selection and outdoor seating. 

If you have a little extra time for lunch on a sunny weekday afternoon, the outdoor area is a nice spot for a more leisurely lunch. The clear canopy lets in the sunshine but keeps the wind at bay. You order along the assembly line and folks bring the food to you once you paid. Service is decently friendly. While the menu is unremarkable, The Iron Cactus is good for groups with something for everyone from salads to tacos to platters. It's also nice that they have "baby" burritos which I found to be quite decently sized for lunch. 

You'll get cheaper beers in nearby bars but to sit out in the sun with a brewski makes the slight premium at The Iron Cactus worth it. If you aren't picky about the food, the outdoor seating is the highlight here.
author: Jon L.

description: Very disappointed in this place. The cashier was on her personal pink phone when I went to order and gave me the "one minute" finger.. only to keep talking to her friends gossiping while customers waited. . Two things me and a friend ordered never arrived and when we asked about those items, she proceeded to tell us both that we never ordered either item and argued about it. Customer service is terrible and the food is mediocre :( will never be back!
author: jeniel s.

description: Fucking horrible... Everything was dry, just tasteless
author: Eddie C.

description: Came here trying to find a new lunch spot for work. Seriously? I know San Francisco prices, but $8 for a freaking bean rice burrito? What a joke. When I asked they said they charged me for a veggie burrito, which is not what I ordered, and this is literally the tinniest burrito I've ever seen. Not to mention the stale rice! Yeah, no thanks guys. I'll wait until after work to get my burrito fix if that's the way you guys wanna play ball.
author: Blake G.

description: Food is bland and service is salty. Asked for two wet burritos. Only one was prepared correctly. When we pointed this out they denied we requested for both and wanted to charge us an extra $1.75 (menu board shows $1.50)! All this after we dropped them a $5 tip. So we demanded our $ back they initially refused then gave in. Shook their head while fixing the burrito as we had originally ordered and paid for (they already charged us $1.50). Horrible customer service. Plus our food including nachos was tasteless. One star cause place is huge with comfortable seating. As someone else said would return only to order a drink and chill.
author: CJ C.

description:
I have fallen in love with this place for their $1 Street Tacos during their happy hour and Tuesday evenings. I keep telling myself to try another taqueria but deep down I know I probably will not be able to find anyplace this tasty and affordable. One Taco Tuesday night while feeling particularly glutenous I ordered 2 tacos of each of their 7 meat choices to split with my bf. We were both beyond stuffed at the end of the meal; where else in SoMa can get two people that full for $14? Now I just stick with 4-6 tacos for a meal that is still very filling. 

My favorite of the meat choices is the Al Pastor (bbq pork) the tender flavorful pork with sweet tart chunks of pineapple is the best. Next would probably be the Chorizo, one time it was a bit salty but it was still delicious. All of the meats are great I think the only one that I didn't find awesome was the  Pollo Roja (red chile chicken?). 

Also, the staff has been really great; friendly and patient with complicated orders. This has been the one place that when I asked for something without one component they asked what I would like to substitute it with. This may be weird to say but the older lady there always seems to be in a good mood (smiling and what not) and it is super adorable. 

Let's see what else; the Horchata is really really good as well creamy, sweet, refreshing, and a nice counterpoint to spicy and salty tacos. The super nachos were really good and can be a meal for two.
 
All in all this place is awesome like as good as it gets awesome for the location and price. Tuesday has now become Taco Tuesday night at my place and we have been coming into The Iron Cactus for months now and I don't foresee any ending the new tradition.
author: Corrie C.

description:
I'm not really sure why this spot get's such a poor rating. I usually get take out because I work at the HD Buttercup next door, but the staff is friendly, they get my order right, and I'm in/ out and on my way. If you're looking for something casual and quick Iron Cactus is good check out. ENJOY!

PS: Chips with each order. :)
author: Darlene Y.

description: I've been going here on the way into the ballpark for many years. ALWAYS good. A much better version of Chipotle. I have no idea why the rating is so low. The burrito bowl is my go to but I've had other things here. Consistently excellent.
author: Frank C.

description: Great happy hour with $3 beers, $1 tacos and spectacular guacamole. The lady who works the taco bar gives wonderful customer service and makes the vibe very friendly.
author: Joseph B.

description:
I am pretty much vegetarian and dislike tofu so I cannot speak to the meat/tofu burritos, tacos, etc. However, I LOVE their cheese quesadilla with beans and rice and a small side of sour cream. I know it's pretty much comfort, but it's so yummy! 

Other pros:
-Helpful and nice staff
-Efficient service
-Heavy pours of wine/beer 
-Clean place
-Free chips and salsa if you order an entree 
-Close to AT&T Park and Caltrain stop
author: Megan B.

description:
The decor and atmosphere here is really cool but the service and food not so much. 

Lunch can be a CRAZY and PRICEY wait but that's expected around this neighborhood. 

I've tried their tacos, chimichangas, and steak torta special. I wouldn't recommend their tacos or anything carne asada to be honest. It's super dried up and bland. 

Another plus is that you can drench their food with their sauces - make it easy that you don't have to ask them for extra when you can pack it yourself.
author: Yen Yen C.

description:
Decent Mexican food. More like a chipotle than authentic though. Fast, quick and easy  

Taco Tuesday $1 tacos are a plus. Don't come on a game day otherwise they won't honor it. Salsas are bomb. Can't complain. 

Pricey for a quick bite but it's soma and in the city so it's expected.
author: Shellie H.

description: Being close to work, have lunch here many times. Food does not feel good here. Many times ingredients used feel stale & very bland. There are lovely ladies working here but sadly food isn't up to the mark. Have found a better place for Mexican lunch now.
author: Vipul Z.

description:
Everytime I've been to Iron Cactus they either mess up or forget my order. Today was no exception. What self-respecting Mexican restaurant does not have rice? 20 minutes? No, thanks.

This place could be very good, but it relies too heavily on its convenience/location and not enough on producing good food. Lacking consistency, I'll give it 2-stars.
author: Be N.

description: I try Iron Cactus once a year and it never gets any better. I hate to downgrade my rating but its just not reflective of the present situation. Please improve.  We need good Mexican food in SOMA.
author: Rosie L.

description: Staff was friendly, but the food was incredibly bland. The carne asada was gray? The food is also overpriced - basically not worth it. They also decided to clean the floors during business hours so it was pretty awful trying to eat their mediocre Mexican food with the smell of bleach and other cleaning supplies. Wouldn't come back.
author: Michelle N.

description: It says "taqueria" on the outside, don't be fooled it's not. It's attached to the Creamery, that should be your first clue. Location is decent as it's adjacent to caltrain but if you have a few minutes to spare go elsewhere for your Mexican cravings. The super carne asada burrito I got was $9.50 and worth maybe $5 of it. Little, fairly bland and gummy.
author: Mark C.

description:
Service was bad and confusing. I've had my fair share of burritos, and the iron cactus is by far the worst I've had. Ever. 
 
The Pastor was too sweet and obviously wasn't marinated with the correct spices or even cooked properly for that matter. The beans were stale tasting which was alarming, and the rice just seemed old! 

Truly disappointed, will think twice about coming back.
author: Luis A.

description: It's like a Chipotle but with stale food because there is never anyone in there to eat it.
author: Christian C.

description:
This is a review for mainly for their catering and delivery services. 

The food is great, so lets just get that out of the way. No complaints and the food tastes fresh and yummy every time.

For catering/delivery: I place catering orders weekly and Iron Cactus is my #1 favorite to order from because of how convenient it is. Ivor makes the whole process really easy and responds to emails quickly. The delivery guy is SUPER nice, he helps you set up and-the best part-they are always EARLY if not on time. But for me they've always been early, which is RARE if you know the struggles of getting catering to your office in down town SF.

I feel bad that it's taken me this long to write a review, but thank you for your wonderful service and great food. My coworkers LOVE the food so just keep up the fantastic work!
author: Lauren T.

description: This is the go-to place if you want some great inexpensive food.  On tuesdays from 6 to closing (8pm) they have dollar street tacos. You have seven choices of meat. My favorites are chorizo and the el pastor. The dollar tacos are great, along with the beef rancheros and their super nachos. Also, you should try their horchata drink.  The service there is also great. The only complain I have is that when you order, they give you your bill which you give right back to them at the counter which is weird.
author: Mark W.

description:
Apparently in SF, places close between lunch & dinner -_-
So we settled for this place.
This place is huge inside, decked out in Giants & Warriors swag!
Reminded me of a turu-turu, the food is in front of you VIA cafeteria style. 

The employees were too busy talking to each other even after they looked at us they kept their little conversation going before finally asking us if we were ready.
BTW; we did look ready since WE WERE STARVING!

I ordered the Cheese Quesadilla, simple.
When we got to the cashier, we paid & were given a small basket of chips. Just chips, no salsa or anything.

We got the Coke in a bottle to drink :)
They gave us a number to put on the table.

Our food came out quick. My quesadilla was surprisingly bigger than I expected :) I asked for Guac on the side (not bad) It was good, how can you really go wrong with it? Just sayin'

They had TV's on playing ESPN so that is always a PLUS!

I saw people leave their dishes on their table & leave, then I also saw people put their dishes in the bus carts, we opted for that. 

Their bathrooms are only on stalls, FYI.

All in all, it was okay.
author: Camille C.

description: Spacious place, good Mexican food. This should have more than stars than it currently has.
author: Hari Krishn G.

description: Very plain Mexican food, not horrible, but probably only a place you frequent if you're nearby or in a pinch. Menu is pretty large and they had an interesting chorizo egg torta special, so maybe they have some hidden gems if you taste enough things. No salsa bar and the chips are extra, and few.
author: Gonzalo S.

description:
When I looked through the window and the place was empty, I was hopeful it was just a fluke. I was sadly mistaken. The atmosphere was cool, the staff was nice enough... Things not to order... Steak Fajitas, Steak burrito (too dry) Wet steak burrito... Chicken tortilla soup. All pretty flavorless. Chips and salsa also don't come with the meal, you can buy it separately for $5 and they look like they came right off the grocery store shelf...
Just pop off the lid. There was silverware, but drinks come in a solo cup or tin can. Sorry...
author: Kim G.

description: It's easy to slam this place as too "Chipotle-like" and the fact that it's the same owner as the Crepe place next door, but hell, it's one of the few Mexican places that actually serve my tacos al pastor.  Spacious place and sangrias.  I can be a simple gal to please.
author: Bailey N.

description: Only had the super nachos & burrito but both are pretty good . Grilled chicken was good
author: Paul B.

description:
Pretty bad Mexican. Yelp was spot on with a 2 1/2 star rating. Tried the Carnitas, Pastor, Chorizo and the chicken. Everything either lacked flavor or was a miss. Even the chips and gauc were subpar


Pass
author: Jeff F.

description:
4/26/2013:

The Iron Cactus is awesome, what more can I ask for? When I am getting of Caltrain looking for a place to statisfy my craving for Mexican food, this is the restaurant to go to! A taqueria right by Caltrain Station? Awesome!

I was craving for some rice so I came in and ordered a small box of seasoned rice with pork. This was delicious, I'm craving for rice and pork with refried beans as I write this update.

Customer service here is efficient, staff members here are nice and the menu items are reasonably priced. If you're looking for a taqueria right after getting off Caltrain or before getting on Caltrain, this is the place to go to.
author: Bennett W.

description:
The Iron Cactus benefits highly from its location - Caltrain and Giants game traffic.

I'm not sure what an iron cactus would taste like - but their burritos probably are close.

Flavorless, sloppy. You can do better going to Whole Foods up the street. Yes, I said that.
author: D C.

description: A bit surprised at some of the negative reviews. I come here on a regular basis with my 2 pups. The people who work here are truly lovely -- always a smile -- a real one. And they couldn't be any sweeter to my boys. The place is very chill -- low key vibe with a few sports tvs to keep you up on the latest Giants beating. The food is better than average pub fare -- and for the price, this is pretty authentic mexican food.
author: Teet S.

description:
Not much food in this area, for I had about an hour an half of time to kill so I thought I'd stop in for a beer and nachos. 

Corona light on draft is definitely a plus for me. 
Nachos can quick and were tasty, and with an ice cold beer on I cannot complain.

It's a bit stuffy in here and didn't notice the outside seating until it was too late. 

Decent food and decent prices I guess. Really nothing to rave about but nothing to hate either.
author: Mona A.

description: I am working in the neighborhood, so I thought I would try it.  The staff is very friendly, and the place is inviting.  I got a burrito and it was pretty good, they are just a little lean on the meat, it was mostly rice and beans.  I have eaten here several times, and have had the same experience every time, so ask for extra meat.  Other than that the place is clean, and the food is fast
author: Paul G.

description: Avoid the seafood, chicken and pork are OK. Don't get fancy at this place, half the stuff is microwaved.
author: H. T.

description:
So I come here all the time for lunch since my office is nearby. The last two experiences here were HORRIBLE!!! So, the first bad experience happened when I ordered the carne asada plate and they give me a shrimp and carne asada plate and I asked if they can take it back because I am allergic to shrimp. The lady takes it back and I see her just take the shrimp off my plate and try to reserve the plate to me. So I told the lady I didn't want it and would like my money back. She told me she wouldn't give me my money back, so I asked to see the manager. I explained everything to the manager and he took care of it. Gave me my money back and brought me my correct order. So I thought everything was good, right? 

Then the next time I went there the same lady who wouldn't give me my money back was at the cashier. I ordered a burrito and right when I was about to pay she switched with someone else and went to talk to the other ladies who was making the food and they all looked back and smiled at me. Something is up right? So my order number is 50 and I see them making all the food (because it's made in the front) and I hear 47, 48, 49 and I see that they took my burrito to the back. The same sneaky lady saw me see that whole thing happened and then asked for my order number when they brought my burrito out from the back! And I didn't say anything back to her and then she called out 37! Can you believe that? This bitch was about to give me fucked up food they did in the back. So, I just cancelled my order and got my money back. SHADY ASS LADY AND WORKERS!
author: stacy t.

description:
High ceilings, large, open space with multiple flat screens to catch your favorite game.
They have a quite wide variety in their menu and drinks on tap. 
While I appreciate their portion size (my fish tacos plate came with side of guac, sour cream, black beans with cheese and 3 fish tacos), I rather they focus on the food quality. My fish taco was pretty unappetizing...tasted like frozen fish, and I even found a big bone inside...unacceptable. 
We also got their chips and salsa, which was decent, but nothing special. Their guac was a bit watered down as well. 
Maybe their other food would be better. I would say, come here to catch a game and order drinks, as they have beer on tap. Skip their food.
author: Nancy Z.

description:
Ignoring that Iron Cactus is connected to The Creamery next door, the decor is the best thing about this place - High ceilings, exposed wood beams, wooden tables and chairs, and lots of pride for SF sports teams. 

The food on the other hand, is nothing to write home about. I ordered a steak taco and a spicy chicken taco. The steak was tough and overcooked. The chicken was flavorful and tender, but impossible to pick up because the juices had so thoroughly soaked through the tasteless, obviously store bought tortilla.

For $3.50 (+$1 more for guacamole) per taco, the price was alright, but the flavors and textures left me wishing I'd walked the few extra blocks to Garaje instead. I won't make the same mistake twice.
author: Cindy T.

description: Some of the worst Mexican food I've ever had. Absolutely awful. The enchiladas were dry, bland, and hardly resembled an enchilada at all. The sides were okay--not great. The staff was nice and it had a good atmosphere. Overall, would not recommend.
author: Maggie T.

description: I'm pretty disappointed. I just got myself lunch from this place and brought $25 cash thinking that would be more than enough for lunch for 1 person. I ordered 2 crispy tacos with chicken, a cheese quesadilla (which is one tortilla, not 2) and a small chips and salsa. It came out to over $26 dollars I was shocked. I canceled the chips and salsa and came out to $24. When I got my receipt I was charged for a large salsa for $3. I questioned why that was on my bill since I canceled any salsa I ordered and she rolled her eyes and gave me my $3 back. When I got home, I opened the box to find my tacos were not crispy as I ordered, but soft. Next time I have a Mexican Food craving, I'm going to Victors which is way better a block away. Don't waste your money.
author: Micky C.

description:
My lunchtime experience at The Iron Cactus today was nothing short of utter disappointment. I expected a quick and simple order/sit down transaction that I would get at any neighborhood taqueria in the city but left frustrated with the complications of this establishment. 

The cafeteria-style ordering process seemed great for me -- "get it and go" was what I had expected. Unfortunately, this seemed to me the longest and most disappointing restaurant experience that I'd had in a while. At checkout, the cashier (manager on duty) rung me up thrice for the wrong order! My order was apparently taken down incorrectly by the lady at the counter, and the manager called her out on writing the wrong order front of me and the rest of the line; I found this really unprofessional, as he could have just as easily quietly adjusted my order. 

I waited for my order for a good 15-20 minutes before the manager assured me that it'd be out soon. He came back with a plate for me and scurried off quickly before I could even catch that I was given the wrong order! What is going on in this place?! 

I brought my food back to the counter and was passed off from server to server and ignored for my refund request by the cashier before I located the manager next door at The Creamery to fulfill my request. He refunded me in cash and seemed apathetic to my horrible customer experience. 

Lunch hour was wasted, and I'm never coming back here again. Don't waste your time.
author: Angel V.

description:
loved the setup of the place.
Food was alright. We had to wait about 20 minutes for a clean fork while lunching there at around 2pm.

Loved the ambiance and the setup.
author: Al S.

description: I'm surprised by other reviews saying no one goes here because we've been here at least five times and every time it's crowded and delicious and inexpensive as well. The fish tacos are awesomeness! Everything we've ordered has been fresh, tasty and fast. If you're headed to AT&T park it's a great little spot.
author: Sharon S.

description: Really nice ladies that work there. The food is mediocre and bland. No flavor! I don't know why the Al Pastor meat is so sweat and gross. Taste sort of like tinga, which some of you never had before lol. Chorizo was too salty and tasted weird.. Only thing decent here is the nachos and crispy chicken tacos. Their salsa game is weak
author: Oskar D.

description: Always had a good experience here. Usually take out burritos to bring into the Giants game or a quick bite before the game. It may be that our expectations are in line with what we get since we have been here a few times and will return. I don't mind if it stays off the most popular list so we can get a table outside, but would like it to stay around for years to come. The construction out front will end some day!
author: Chuck M.

description:
Typical Mexican taqueria in a not so typical location which is great for large group lunches!

I wouldn't ever say that I want to go here in my free time, but there is no better place for quick services and big tables for a business lunch. The food is decent and the menu is expansive. It will defiantly solve your Mexican addictions while allowing you to seat a bunch of folks indoors or outside when the sun is out. One funny little feature is the direct access to the Creamery which is the best local spot to pay too much for absolutely nothing. 

Anyway, head here for Mexican with a group of friends for lunch when you want solid food, but not for any other reason.
author: Steven C.

description: Came here for $1 taco Tuesday . The tacos had so little in it that it felt as if I were just eating tortillas. There was literally 5 tiny pieces of meat and 3 little pieces of onion. Paid $1 for two tortillas.
author: Amanda T.

description: I've tried to give this place a few chances since it was the only taco shop I knew of since moving to my new place in the area. The staff never seems to understand what I want and argued about making me a plain bean burrito. Even after I managed to get them to make one for me they still charged me the outrageous full price for only a tortilla and beans. When I got it out of the bag they did not even attempt to wrap it properly. One plus for them is that they do have vegan beans that they make themselves.
author: Hannah L.

description: It's like a Chipotle wannabe...but with del Taco flavor. I've been several times now, both times it left much to be desired, plus, they make their margaritas with wine!  Major hard pass.
author: Hayley H.

description:
I had a late evening meeting in San Francisco with some startup folks and was running late.  Weaving through traffic, I managed to find a decent parking spot right near The Iron Cactus and dashed in for my meeting and some tacos.  As it turns out, it was Taco Tuesday and $1 tacos sounded divine.

While the meeting went really well and opened my eyes to the many challenges that startups face, the food disappointed like mad.  I ordered 3 of their Taco Tuesday specials with carne asada, pollo asada, and carnitas.  Topped with only raw onions and cilantro, the tacos were extremely bland and the onions were really overpowering.  Even topped with two of their salsas didn't seem to improve them.  They may only have been $1, but I'm not sure they were worth that much.  The other menu items were significantly more expensive but after trying their popular tacos, I can't really figure out why they are so.

The location is really convenient if you work in the SOMA area especially since it is right next to the Caltrain station.  They've got cheap drinks and a super dog-friendly patio too.  People bring their pets out all the time so you know it's a popular spot for the pooches.  Their big on sustainability too so maybe I'll give this place another shot especially if I need a taco fix.  I'm definitely asking for less onion though.

Food: 4/10

Service: 5/10

Price: $

Atmosphere: 6/10
author: Joe M.

description: If you're in a pinch I could see why you would come to Iron Cactus. The food is fairly priced but it's a bit dry. The tacos are usually your best bet here.
author: Tim M.

description: Staff was beyond super rude! I had missed my train and all I needed was some dinner and a drink after a super long 15 hour work day.  Walked in 10 minutes before close. Staff at counter were non-attentive, once I caught their attention staff told me I couldn't stay because they were closing. There are multiple people sitting at tables enjoying meals all I needed was 15 to 20 minutes before my next train.  This restaurant is on my daily commuter path.  I will not be bringing business, clients or friends here in the future. Super disappointed in quality of customer service!
author: Elizabeth B.

description: I'm still wondering why i find myself coming back to this place. It is extremely overpriced for what it is. I ordered a burrito and paid for "extra cheese" and when I bit into my "super" burrito I found barely any cheese! And I was pregnant at the time. All I wanted was some extra cheese! It was first thing when they opened too so its not like they were swamped or low on food. Sadly, I will probably keep going to this overpriced, unauthentic Mexican food place...for reasons unknown.
author: Andy S.

description:
*Rant coming*
Wow, I'm shocked by the other reviews.  Some complaining about the "quality", others about the "quantity", others about the "pricing"...talk about hypercritical yelpers.

Sure, you can get cheaper, but you'd sacrifice quality as well as atmosphere.  Sure you can get better, but you'll certainly pay for it.  Sure, you can get more, but you'll probably sacrifice quality and pricing.  
*Rant ended*

Now, the rexiew...

The spot is in a perfect location first of all.  We jumped off Caltrain on our way to AT&T park, but instead of paying $20+ for junk food there, we saw this across the street from the train station and headed over.  First, I was pretty impressed by their menu.  A good variety of typical Mexican taqueria classics, plus an added bonus for me.  They actually have an alternative to meat which isn't very common in Mexican spots.  They had tofu burritos.  Love it.  

On top of the diverse menu, the atmosphere is pretty cool.  Certainly nicer than a typical hole in the wall taqueria, more restaurant vibe.  Lots of vintage(or vintage looking) wood, bid tables, consistent decor.  It all fits the vibe well.  It is an "order and sit" spot, which is nice and casual.  The people working there were super nice and friendly.

Now to the food...the food was good.  
Was it the best Mexican food ever?  No.  
Was it quality?  Yes.  
Were the portions substantial?  Yes.  
(People were complaining about "small sizes", I'm a 6'2" 200lb athlete, and I was full on a burrito.)
Was it worth the $? Yes. 
(We had two meals and a sangria for $20.)

I'd certainly come back next time I'm hitting a Giants game, probably try something different for fun next time.
author: Sean M.

description: Keep walking.  ;-)
author: Be F.

description:
Ehh but not ahh.

The food was okay for the cheap price, but the service was not impressive. The food just seemed to skimp on all the good stuff to make way for rice?

So the average to mediocre food combined with the agitating service is the reason for the 3.
author: Jeffery H.

description:
My lunch at the Iron Cactus was a truly unique dining experience.

We had 6 people at our table. The first remarkable thing was that the kitchen managed to get every single order wrong. Fortunately, it doesn't take long to make this sort of food so they got it straightened out after everything got sent back.

The next amazing thing was the total lack of utensils, napkins, and salsa. I mean we actually had to get up from the table and go prospecting around the place looking for stuff. The waiter apparently is used to this and smiled benignly as we ran around gathering up what we needed for eating.

The final straw, for me at least, was that they tried to kill me. Literally. Cleverly hidden in my soft-shell taco was a 2 inch piece of steel wire. Words cannot describe how grateful I am to my mother for teaching me not to wolf my food as a kid. Anyway, having narrowly escaped death, I was content to sip my horchata and watch the rest of my companions tempt fate.

Forewarned is forearmed, of course, and now my friends were picking through their food with great care. One of them found a metal shard in his enchilada - not as deadly as a piece of wire but worth a broken tooth or a trip to the ER.

I would give this place a miss unless you are keen on risking serious bodily injury for really sub-par Mexican food.
author: Bret F.

description:
let shib tell u abt shib's experiance here. LET SHIB TELL U.

shib want to come inside 4 fud. so shib walk inside. then, shib smelling something. *sniff sniff* wow. smell like shib's private part. BUT SHIB SUCH HUNGER. shib trai to turn off super sensitiv nose. then shib go order. "1 burrito plz"

shib sit down. smell even stronger. SHIB IS DYING.

fud come. burrito is ok size. burrito on such plate. plate is much wet. WAI. plate smell like stale chlorine watar. EEEEEEEEEEEËEEE. burrito wrappar is wet. ÉeeeeeeEEE.

shib bite into burrito. meh. chew chew. meh. chew chew chew. smell el terrible privat part smell. EEEEEEEEEE. shib barf. shib eat bar, bcuz taste bettar. 

0 speshul. shib can make such bettar burrito at shib home.

poop.
author: Doge S.

description:
In SOMA, this can be a good spot for a quick decent lunch, but don't expect anything special. I had a super burrito and found it filling and appetizing, but it could have also be a lot better. Most burritos nearby will beat it. 

I think it's a shame they only have salsas that can be put into a ketchup bottle. If it can squeeze out of a small hole, there is something wrong with it. What happened to thick and chunky? 

There is plenty of outdoor seating, but if there is a breeze or cloudy, it could be too chilly. In that case, good luck finding a seat inside.

I am giving it a 2 because I probably wouldn't recommend this under normal circumstances.
author: Andrew H.

description:
Just a little better then Taco Bell. I've been there 3 times and they've always messed up my order. 

Food is subpar. 

Only relevant because of their convenient location.
author: Ari M.

description:
First time there 
The food was good, it´s not the best mexican food I had but it´s ok for the price and the quantity. 
They deserve more than 2 stars 
Bad review for the waitress who wasn't nice.
author: Laura B.

description:
Yay! Im a fan! This has always looked like a fun place to go for game watching/drinking. Usually looks busy with good looking people inside.

Came in before the Beyonce/HOV concert. We were in a hurry, so I ordered the Super Burrito with black beans and grilled chicken. The burrito was ready about 15mins later (it was packed in there). We waited in the other room, which is an indoor/outdoor cafe that shares the building. The bathroom was huge, and because there was a bathroom on each side of the building, even though it was packed, I didnt have to wait long.

Ate the burrito on the way to AT&T park. BOMB. Smashed it by the time I passed through the metal detectors. Yum-o.
author: Ashley J.

description: If you're in the mood for Mexican food, or even Mexican-like food, this is not the place. The salsas are unremarkable and not spicy or tasty. I had the tostada salad bowl with al pastor and black beans -- I've never in my life had sweetish al pastor and the beans were right out of the can -- no seasoning at all. The rice and even the guac were tasteless, too. My SO had 3 enchiladas with three different meats in them and couldn't tell the difference between the steak, chicken, and pork! Yikes. How this place has stayed in business is beyond me.
author: Diane K.

description:
I'm a bit surprised how much the Iron Cactus has gotten slammed since its opening just a month ago. Either the place made one very bad first impression with those anxious for its opening, or perhaps some of the more vociferous customers may have sat on an actual iron cactus and still feel the searing pain of the needles stuck in their.... Judging from my experience, I have a feeling it's somewhere in between, but I say give it time to get better since the owner seems to be trying hard to become a casual place for locals and Caltrans commuters looking for California-accented Mexican food and beer on tap. 

I was there with Jamie W. for a local community get-together, so I may not have had the most unbiased experience since we were fortunate enough to get a small sampling of several dishes. I admit I didn't feel anything was a complete standout, but a few were on their way to pretty darn good. The $5.25 Ceviche Tostada was a nice treat with shrimp piled high with cilantro on big tortilla chips. The one drawback was that they were a bit too lemony to be completely satisfying.

I also tried their $5.95 Baby Burritos, nicely palm-size and packed full of carnitas, rice, beans, salsa and sour cream. The $4.95 Cheese Quesadillas were definitely on the greasy side, but gooey cheese is hard to resist in any shape, and the $3.50 Soft Asada Taco was tasty but messy to pick up. The interior is very communal and loft-like befitting its deep SoMa locale. All in all, I'd say it's a place to grab a quick bite and hang a bit with friends. If your friends aren't picky eaters, I think you're set. 

FOOD - 3 stars...reasonably good Mexican by way of SoCal 
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...warm vibe for those willing to stick around 
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...I really thought they were pretty nice 
TOTAL - 3 stars...the daggers are out for this place, but trust me, you can do far worse than sitting on an iron cactus
author: Ed U.

description:
Considering how much I loathe Victor's around the block I was excited when I realized The Iron Cactus (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZIe-mxk6KWq_ht1jcQ_pAg?select=H9qhiOiC--8oQOFUzTEO8g) had opened up for business.  My excitement was short-lived though.

I had lunch here on Friday morning.  I managed to get in just before the crunch of the lunch time masses.  You order at the counter and you're given a number.  You pay and you wait for your number to be called.  I had been watching how some of the items were being prepared and I noticed the regular burrito was only slightly larger than a baby burrito.  I ordered a Crispy Taco plate with pollo asado (grilled chicken).  Rice, choice of beans and a green salad come with the tacos.  As is my norm I chose the whole black beans although it was interesting to see that they offer refried black beans in addition to the regular refried beans.

The person that takes your order is the person that prepares your food.  The wait for my food was fairly short.  For take out orders I notice they use biodegradable utensils.  You can also use metal utensils if you're eating in.  The interior is very nice with lots of wood tones.

My taco plate (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZIe-mxk6KWq_ht1jcQ_pAg?select=uW_66S5sI52FAQpT5UtmHA) looked pretty good.  My food preparer put lots of chicken meat into the crispy taco shells, but she forgot to give me cheese.  Sour cream, guacamole and pico de gallo (salsa) come on the plate along with the rice, salad and beans.  The chicken was all big chunks of warm, tender, moist chicken breast.  The orange colored seasoning on the chicken was not well defined though and the chicken just tasted bland.  I added parts of my salad, which is served plain with a small lemon wedge, into the taco shell along with the sour cream, the guac and the salsa.

I like chunky guacamole and the avocado here is whipped up too smoothly.  It kind of just ran off of the taco shell instead of staying put.  The Spanish rice mixed with peas and corn was just slightly warm too.  The place is still new so I kind of expect some of the shortfalls.  I'll definitely come back again.  For now they're still better than Victor's but very average.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description:
Date & Time:  Wednesday October 21, 2009 @ 6:30pm Opening Day
Company:  Mommy & Michael
Crowd:  Neighborhood Condo-Dwellers & Young Families w/ Mclaren Strollers
Vibe:  Chill
Music:  Salsa
Decor:  Rustic.  Communal Tables, Bench-Seating &  Charming Back Patio
Service:  Nice & Friendly
Imbibe:  Horchata.   Wine & Beer Available
Devour:  Fish Tacos, Beef Tacos & Quesadilla Carnitas
Total:  $20.73
author: Genevieve Y.

description:
Three words: rancid fish tacos. 

The Iron Cactus is bland at best, disgusting at worst, and an abomination to Mexican cuisine everywhere. 

Unless I find myself in desperate need of a low-budget, flavorless stomach filler, I will not be returning.
author: Cynthia M.

description:
I live down the street and like the food.

I've never been able to take advantage of happy hour prices. They usually cancel it for Giants' games, but like today, they also cancel if for "other events." It's not so important, but it's a letdown when you get your friends excited for $1 tacos, only to find each time that they canceled it.

Update: There actually was a concert at the stadium tonight.
author: Jeffrey Y.

description:
Great atmosphere, especially if you are a sports fan.

I have been here several times, and ordered their super burrito, chicken fajitas, and one of their Mexican-style salads. The food is not overwhelmingly good, but it is filling. Their dishes are somewhat bland, especially their meats, which I don't think is properly seasoned or marinated. The Spanish rice is really dry as well.

There are free chips and salsa, which is always nice.
author: Favian S.

description:
Iron Cactus offers solid Mexican food at a fair price in SOMA.  The patio in the back is nice on a sunny day and offers a bit of protection from the inevitable San Francisco wind. I really wanted a salad with tofu and they were able to hook me up despite not having one on a menu. It was a bit of hoopla getting this figured out as the conversation went something like this:

"Can you make a salad with tofu instead of meat?"

"Sure, which salad would you like?"

"They all look pretty much the same but just with different meats, so I'll take something with tofu"

"Yeah but which one would you like with tofu?"

(repeat this back and forth for a couple minutes)

"Ok, if I have to decide, how about the shrimp salad?"

"The shrimp salad with tofu? Well here's the deal, I'm going to make you the chicken salad with tofu"

Like I didn't give him the power to do this at the start. 

My advice, would be to trek to the Mission or go with a different cuisine. If you have to have Mexican though and you're not leaving SOMA you could probably do worse than Iron Cactus.
author: Stephen S.

description:
Worst chips and guac ever. Soggy chips, off-color guac with too much tomato and not enough avocado, and a bunch of stale pico on the side? Awful!

Margarita was fine though. 

Decorations make this place look a lot better than it actually is.
author: Alan H.

description:
Now this is one location where I don't understand the low stars. This is my second time here and my service was OK (not good for so wine to say ok) but my food was slammin. 

I got the enchilada plate and every time it's actually better. What has me addicted is the 5 dollar glass of sangria. It's good and my glass is big. Loves!!!
author: Sophie P.

description:
I hit this spot regularly because it is conveniently located about a block away from where I work. To me, their food is about on the same level as a place like Chipotle. The burritos are filling, none of the salsas are overpoweringly hot and they boast a decent selection of meat options. Chances are if you have a hangup about your Mexican food being "authentic", whatever your version of authentic might be, you'll be disappointed with this place.

If you use the Yelp app on your smart phone, make sure you check in on Tuesdays. Their check-in offer is good for $1 street tacos, $2 Coronas and $10 for a bucket of Coronas on Tuesdays only. If you're in town for a Giants game, this is definitely a good place to eat and sip before you have to head to the game and pay ballpark prices. They also boast a decent selection of beer on tap if you're like me and don't particularly like drinking watery yellow beer. 

This place is also attached to the hipster deli/cafe place next door, so if you're with someone who doesn't feel like taqueria food, they can pick up a sandwich and you can still eat in the same place.
author: Nate R.

description:
Just another taqueria that has the average Mexican food that there is nothing interesting but I usually would get the quesadillas which are good. The things that I like about the place is the location and its linked to The Creamery which is also a good brunch spot. Anyways, their service is like they are serving you in a cafeteria or like at a Chinese restaurant. I like the setting and the atmosphere plus it's good spot to watch sports games with your friends. 

Is there any good taqueria spots that are legit?
author: Ahrmon R.

description:
I would say that this is 3.5 stars!

Iron Cactus has the best green salsa that I have found in San Francisco thus far.  If you don't know already, I moved up from San Diego, and have been on the lookout for the best sauces in San Francisco.  Nothing even compares to San Diego so far.

I got a regular burrito here.  Service was fast, friendly, and there was plenty of room to sit!  It's close to a lot of bus stops + muni stops + the cal train station, so it's a nice place to meet up before a game or after work before you head home.

Food was okay.  Chicken was delicious, but they put too much rice in my burrito.  Burritos were pretty reasonably priced though -- especially for SF!  I wouldn't mind coming back here again.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Super fast service, staff was friendly, and the food was delicious. A little more expensive than other Mexican food places in the area, but worth it!
author: Michelle A.

description: Wow this place has gotten mad slammed in the review department. I cannot confirm or deny the ratings in the cuisine but since it was a reallly hot day and they had the Mexican watermelon juice. That was pretty decent. So do I dare try the food?
author: Kim N.

description: The super  quesadilla w/pastor was great. Can't say the same for the super taco. 3 for service since my order is wrong half the time. But otherwise great the food, beer selection, and a place to watch sports.
author: JJ S.

description: Every time I come here I think to myself "the food is good, but the service sucks. But I'll try it one more time." And every time, the food is good, but the service sucks. It took 29 mins to get my nachos from the time I ordered it and upon having me my food they said, "we close in 6 minutes." Ummm... Yea, despite the good food the servers are super rude.
author: E L.

description:
On my way back to the train station my friend and I were looking for a quick bite before our journey back home. My friend walked into this place and said this OK? Without consulting Yelp I said sure so we ordered some burritos, it didn't look all that great as all the food had been cooked and it looked like all of it had been sitting in the bins for quite some time. As I was waiting for my food I checked in and it was then I saw the 2-1/2 star rating, oh boy, here we go. So I was sitting there for a while and then I noticed a burrito sitting on the counter so I walked up to it and asked if it was mine and sure enough it was but nobody called my name or said anything, it was at the opposite end of where I would have thought to look and the lady was off making someone else's order. So service I would say is non existent, after you order and pay, your on your own.
   The food was just what I expected, not very good. I had a Carne Asada Burrito and you could tell the meat was not very good quality and overall it was just another burrito, nothing special. I try not to be tainted by bad reviews and generally avoid places with bad ratings but this experience just qualified Yelps effectiveness to me. I'm not from SF so it's easy to say I'm not coming back to this place...
author: Mark F.

description:
It's hard to criticize The Iron Cactus for not feeling authentic, it'd be like criticizing a place in the Marina for attracting too many frat-boys or someplace in the Mission for being too faux-dive and only taking cash, some neighborhoods are just known for something, and they cater to their audience. The Iron Cactus is a taqueria in South Beach serving up to the baseball and Caltrain crowd, that's less concerned with authenticity and more concerned with packing their twenty co-workers in for margaritas to watch the game. 

The tacos I got weren't bad, they just felt like something I could make myself at home. (Not like tacos are culinary masterpieces, but you know when they were made with love.) The carnitas were probably the best (when aren't they?), and word is they have a great Taco Tuesday special, so if you're near AT&T Park and craving tacos on a Tuesday night, and any tacos will do, give Iron Cactus a shot. Or catch the bus to the Mission (and bring cash).
author: Kevin B.

description:
$20 for a pitcher of shocktop is a little pricey in my book, especially when a regular glass is $5. However, I guess the environment is a little nicer than any regular taco joint.

Relatively empty at 3:00 on Sunday afternoon. Also, they have signs outside that boast a beer patio, which is just a bunch of wobbly tables outside in the shade (which was cold, even on a relatively warm, SF day).

If you're just looking for a place to grab drinks, I would pass on this restaurant.
author: Michelle L.

description:
I come here because it's close. It's not really special or great, but it's not bad. It's what you would expect. The meat is a bit gray. The guac is a bit gray. The lettuce is a bit pale. The staff isn't particularly nice, but they're not particularly rude.

I always get their tostada salad. It's just a deep fried tortilla bowl filled with your normal burrito toppings.
author: H. L.

description: Service was fine -- no real complaints. Food was just bad. I came here starving before my Caltrain and wanted to kill some time, but I wish I had yelped this place first. I ordered the spicy shrimp salad, which tasted stale and not fresh at all. Shrimp was spicy, but that's probably because it was doused in Sriracha (which makes no sense at all btw)...I couldn't even finish it.
author: Veronica L.

description:
2.5 stars.  If you're craving Mexican just hold out til you can make a trip to the Mission.  

By definition, Al Pastor is marinated pork.  Well, the Al Pastor at the Iron Cactus is dried out beyond belief!  I've noticed other Yelpers have commented that the chicken is dry as well so I'm guessing this is pretty standard.  Due to the dry meat, my quesadilla was dry.  The rice is sort of bland, though it is properly cooked, unlike Primo Patio down the street (I still shudder when I think of the horrific rice I was served there).  The black beans were enjoyable since they were they only non-dry thing on my plate.
author: Beatrice W.

description:
I've eaten here for about 6 meals a week for the last year and a half.

The food is delicious (a tad more expensive than other taquerias, but it's near the park, so I guess it is justified), and the ingredients are fresh almost all the time (less so about 15m before closing, but still not too bad.)

I also always have a very specific and customized order, and they're pretty good about getting it exactly right.

There is rarely a line, and their service is pretty quick (even during busy lunch hours).
author: Raaid A.

description:
Went here with a very small group for lunch. Not the greatest experience.

I ordered a salad, without meat and subbed tofu in. They wrote it down on the ticket and everything, first salad comes, no tofu and it had mango on it. Mango unfortunately, was not listed in the salad's description. Now usually I view additional food served as a good thing, but not when I am allergic to it. 

I ask the server to bring a new salad and noted that the first one didn't have tofu as I had asked. Wait a few minutes and he brings me a new salad with no mango and still no tofu. At the point, I just let it slide and went with the lunch.

Just disappointed with the customer service and their lack of attention to detail.

Pros 
- When sunny, the deck is great

Cons 
- Items on the menu feature hidden ingredients
- Not great at subbing meat for cheaper, non-meat products x2
- Not the nicest wait staff, the server bumped into a few patrons while bringing tables food
author: Ninja R.

description:
I live and work in SOMA and by default I've probably been here hundreds of times over the past 5 years. I'm finally writing a review.

I am in LOVE with the Mexican Chicken Salad using their super fresh and tasty green and red salsa as dressing. When I'm being "naughty" you can't go wrong with a burrito, taco plate, nachos, tamales...I just love taqueria food. 

This is definitely NorCal style, a bit on the healthier side which is why I'm addicted.

They also have an awesome back patio and I love their sangria, both red and white.
author: Kelly W.

description:
I wish I can give it ZERO stars, but I'm forced to give it at least 1 star. 
The only reason I've ever ate at Iron Cactus is because it's near my job but every time I go in, I always tell myself that it's going to be the last time .... This time I'm serious. Today was the last time I'll ever eat at Iron Cactus again.

They have horrible service. The staff (including the manager) is so rude. They are ridiculously over priced (I get it, its SF, everything is overpriced). But if you're going to make me pay extra for EVERYTHING and still get my order wrong, then at least it should be AUTHENTIC Mexican food. And Iron Cactus is far from authentic. 

Don't waste your time or money going to Iron Cactus.
author: Priz M.

description: Well, this is my 3rd time there and my last time. Yesterday 7/19, 3 of us when there for lunch around 2:30pm. One of us ordered a super burrito (he was happy with it), the other two of us ordered "steak and prawns" for the price of $11.95. The steak was very, very thing and small as a postal stamp and cold. The shrimp? Where was the shrimp, we got 3 or maybe 4 shrimps. Of course the cover the entire plate with salad. We were very disappointed for the amount of food  compare to the price. The plate was full of beens, salad and rice... What happened to the beef and shrimp. Very sad, but I am not going back there. Please give people more beef and few more shrimps, or lower the price of this plate to $6.95. Thanks.
author: Joe V.

description:
The line: Out the door (welcome to SoMA) & pretty fast

The food: HUGE quantities, average quality

I've tried the rancho steak salad and the chipotle prawn plate. They were each roughly $12 after tax (perhaps a little bit much for Tex-Mex). The Iron Cactus gives you chips with every meal and they have a lil' salsa bar. The steak salad was really good: the meat was cooked perfectly, the mixed greens were fresh, and their house dressing is tasty. 

The prawn plate came with rice, beans, chips and tortillas and was way too much food for me! I guess that's not really something to complain about these days though. However, there was a lot of greasy, seasoned water at the bottom of my to-go box, which was kind of unpleasant. (They should use slotted serving spoons!)

A-Ok. Not bad. Not special.
author: K M.

description: A counter service Mexican restaurant across the street from the Caltrain station. Rustic Mexican decor. Great quick service. Better than average food. Worth a try.
author: Kelly B.

description:
Good service, bad food. I really didn't like it.

I wouldn't consider it Mexican Food. But there is a place about a around the corner that was real authentic Mexican Food. Worth finding.
author: Maria S.

description:
Iron Cactus was neither great nor abhorrent.  In a region rich with great Mexican food options, we found Iron Cactus to be average.  While what we had was alright, as was the service, but nothing makes Iron Cactus stand out.

We forget some of the details, but we ordered a naked burrito type of dish, right Zach?  It was rather cold when we received it, which may be attributed to the wait we had for our food.  It was rather packed at lunch time.  Our order wasn't all that remarkable, was it Zach?  The feelings were neutral, and the act just served to quell hunger.

There is a patio out back that serves as a really nice place for having lunch.  But we don't think it is enough to get us to return, is it Zach?
author: Francis M.

description: Each time I've been here, they've screwed up the order - forgotten chicken, used a different type of bean, etc. and bc of this, it seems to take forever. I feel bad for the guy waiter who has to deal with all of the mistakes. He's gracious and apologetic. Why do I come back?  The food is pretty decent, and we don't have many good Mexican places in the neighborhood.
author: Amy S.

description:
I've been back 5 times since my review. The food is less tasty each visit, and the service slower. They consistently get my order wrong, and it's very simple: no beans/no rice in my burrito. I do love their very spicy yellow salsa, but not enough to make me return.

So just an update to say I no longer eat here, and don't plan on returning, despite still living a stone's throw away. Sad face. :(
author: Greg J.

description: My boyfriend and I have lived across the street for months and never knew of this gem! Great home style Mexican food, good service, the best patio for sunny days and a cold one. We both got the fajitas, one chicken and steak, and it was exactly like if we were eating in his moms Latin kitchen.
author: Jenn B.

description:
$1 tacos & $2 coronas, can't be beat before a weeknight Giants game.
Not the best Mexican food but not bad and during happy hour the prices are decent.  At other times, the prices seem a little high but it is the City.    Food looks pretty fresh, they do make it to order in front of you.

Service wise - I wouldn't rant on bad service because frankly this is self service than anything.   You order at a counter, they bring it to you.  That's what it is.  You want a napkin, get it yourself.   

If you want slightly better food and service, you should visit Pete's Tavern and Pedro's Cantina across from AT&T Park.   P&P has a nice bar and friendly service, lots of tvs and is much cleaner, but you do pay for it.
author: Bob V.

description:
Not impressed with food or service. I got a veggie burrito bowl after verbally wrestling with the staff. I attempted to explain my food allergies in both English and Spanish, neither of which worked. Still not really sure if they were being honest or just agreeing to get me out of their face. ...guess I'll find out in a couple hours if the reaction hits. 
The veggies on the burrito bowl were soggy and poorly cooked. Really just a pile of bland zucchini. 
Gave them two stars instead of one because the rice was pretty good.
author: Natalie P.

description: Went here with my friend, who ordered the shrimp burrito and contracted one of the worst cases of food poisoning I've seen in a while. Would not recommend eating here.
author: Caroline C.

description:
Their fish taco was comprised of a couple tortillas, some beans tossed on top, some veggies, and some nasty crappy fish that had the texture of, looked similar to, and tasted like cheap fish from a $5 Chinese takeout restaurant.

Their carne asada? Salty and dry.

Their garlic prawns? What prawns? Again, $5 Chinese food-like. 

Oh come on, it can't be THAT difficult to get Mexican food right, especially when there are so many examples nearby that you can derive inspiration from!
author: Kazu O.

description:
Ordered 25 minutes ago, and then found out they lost my order. Don't care how good the food is when it gets here. This is unacceptable. I'd hate to see what it's like when it's busy. 

--Jump cut to 15 minutes later--

Then my food arrived and they messed up the order. And it wasn't hot. And there was hardly any meat in it. And they tried to make excuses for why they effed up.

This is the worst taqueria in San Francisco, hands down. If ever a restaurant deserved to go out of business, it's this one. If you go here, you're an outright sucker.
author: Gordon E.

description:
This is our go to Mexican food spot near work.Solid good food and lots of choices. They don't always give chips and when they do, the chips aren't always fresh, but the dishes are acceptable. Mostly friendly staff.

Lots of seating with tables big enough for more than just a couple. 

The fourth star is for the sangria, available all day. You heard it here, folks.
author: Cassie H.

description: The food here isn't bad, but it is a little pricey. I usually get the shrimp tacos and have to tell them to make it non-spicy since I cannot handle any spice at all. They usually stack it with rice and beans (I ask for no beans). They used to give us free chips but now charge $1 per tray. If you have your UCSF badge, you get a discount on your food as well! Their green sauce is great and there's enough seating for group lunches and patio seating as well. They are also connected to the Creamery, so if you don't want Mexican food, you can always order crepes or sandwiches.
author: Stacy H.

description: Lukewarm food, using sour cream (despite asking for none), too close to the ballpark (meal of convenience problems) - best to walk on.
author: Christopher F.

description:
I recently moved into the neighborhood, and have been here a few times since taquerias are hard to find in the area. The food is consistently good (not the most authentic in the world, but hey) and comes in huge portions at reasonable prices. The carnitas in particular is delicious. The atmosphere is nice and relaxed, and I love the Giants ephemera plastered everywhere. The servers have always been polite enough, but pretty disengaged and uncaring.

I came here tonight to have dinner with a friend. I had a taco platter and my friend just ordered a couple of tacos. When I went up to pay my card was declined because I'm livin' the broke life and had less money than I thought I did. I was going to get out some cash when the cashier told me to hold on. I stood there, puzzled. She rang me up again, only this time the total was $8 cheaper. It took me a moment to realize that she had taken my friend's tacos off the bill out of the goodness of her heart. I didn't ask her to, I was more than willing to pay. She just...did it. That's the kind of gesture and commitment to customer service that you see very rarely in this day and age, and will keep me coming back for a long time to come.
author: Chelsea T.

description: I mean if you're expecting service and food like you'd get in the Ritz then I would say that this place isn't for you. That being said I personally like this place especially with a happy hour that is $1 Tacos and $3 Beers. I saw that this place didn't have the greatest rating through Voo (https://tryvoo.com) but the Happy Hour was too good to resist and regardless of other reviews I personally experienced good service and good food (keep in mind that a whole meal for me was under $10!!)
author: Peter B.

description: To all you food critics, you all need a drink, this place is the best south of market Mexican food, you criticize the staff for not understanding, when it's probably you, this staff is the most understanding and hard working, just because you could afford to live in SF give me a break, make your own lunch
author: D S.

description:
Wow, surprised to see the 2.5 average review. I'm in between 3 and 4 stars. 

It's not amazing Hispanic food. With all the great burritos and tacos in this town, the bar is set high and so Iron Cactus falls low. That said, it's a solid place in my neighborhood to go and get a meal which is satisfying and makes me happy. 

The seating deserves a shoutout- long rows of benches kind of family style. I've made friends with strangers because of this. Also huge Giants supporters and show the games which is awesome. 

I've only gone in when there's no line so I can't speak to the crappy service that some others mentioned. 

Not a bad place, but not worth going out of your way for. If you're in the hood, definitely worth a bite.
author: Rebecca L.

description:
Was searching for a good place for a beer and good chips and salsa.   Now I wish I had an Iron Stomach.   :P

Plus they nickel and dime you for anything extra.  Sour cream, etc..
author: Cindy A.

description:
Good stuff. I got two fish tacos, which, as per usual at places like this, were huge and I didn't finish, so I took most of the second one home. I suppose maybe for a normal person they're not huge, but I have a small stomach so two fish tacos usually does me in. Plenty of food. I think anybody would probably at least be satisfied with them, if not totally full, like me. Good tastes. I also got the honeydew water, which was interesting. Little too much pulp for me, I probably wouldn't get it again, but it tasted good.
They were out of forks at the condiment/fork area, so I had to wait for those for a couple minutes, but other than that, there were no issues. I'd go back for a good, quick Mexican lunch. My husband eats there semi-often, I think, because he works in the area, and burritos are his favorite food, so I think if it sucked he wouldn't be eating there. :)
author: Erin A.

description:
One thing I can say about this place, it's fancy. Instead of using small clear plastic cups for free water like most places, they use red solo cups. Yes, just like the ones you use for beer pong.

Other than that, prices are okay, not too expensive. Has a very SOMA presence. Regular burrito goes for $6.99 + tax. Which is about the same prices everywhere around the city. As for size, it's about the same size as a Papalote burrito, but cheaper. Papalote now charges $8.75 + tax for a regular burrito which hurts my wallet. However I grew up in the mission, El farlito has the most affordable burritos and they still make the largest burritos, their portions are very large.
author: Robin L.

description:
This place is excellent!

The food is great, and freshly made! They offer two different salsas: Mild, and actual pico de gallo that really is spicy. It is rather pricy for a burrito, but on point for a plate, which include great fajitas and enchiladas! It is a must try before a Giants game, or an event at nearby AT&T Park! 

I worked nearby for 5+ years, and my coworkers would jump at anybody walking two plus blocks to Iron Cactus! It's that good.
author: Alan G.

description:
WORST. SERVICE. EVER.  (the food aint great either)

It takes a lot to achieve this level of distinction, but I think the staff here was the rudest that I have encountered since moving to San Francisco a year and a half ago.

My company just moved into an office a block away, and a coworker and I decided to check out Iron Cactus for lunch.  The lady taking the orders acted like she was doing us a big favor by even serving us.  Nonetheless, we persevered - paid for our food, and sat down with our numbers.  My coworker got his food pretty fast, but mine didn't come.  We were sitting with our back to the counter (and under a loud TV), so I kept turning around periodically to see if my order was ready.  A few minutes later, I'm approached by an extremely cranky server - 

Cranky lady: "Baby burrito?"  

Me: "Yes, thanks so much!"

Cranky lady: "I called you three times.  You deaf or something?"

Me: "Sorry, I must not have heard"

Cranky lady: "Well, listen better next time" *storms away in a huff*

The food at this place was most definitely not good enough to make up for that kind of service.  It wasn't terrible, but it definitely wasn't worth being lectured by the cranky staff.

The only reason this place doesn't get zero stars (other than the fact that Yelp wont let me give zero stars) is that the interior is pretty cute/inviting.  Especially on a sunny day, it's nice to sit by the window and get some Vitamin D.
author: Gowri R.

description: Hadn't realized I never wrote a review of this place, given that I've worked several blocks away from it for about three years now and have gone from time to time.  Had I written the review three years ago it probably would have been 4 stars at least -- but now it's two.  The quality of their food used to be great -- but it's gone downhill.  First time I've actually tried their cactus salad, with chicken, beef and shrimp.   It's mostly just lettuce!  Poorly constructed.  The chicken is ok, but the beef, which I asked to be cooked well done, really wasn't and was not great quality at all.  The shrimp was meh.  I came with a big appetite and left wanting.   I'll stick with Chipotle, and if that ain't a slap in the face...
author: Merrick W.

description: Not the most authentic burrito place, but for SOMA, this is works. When I'm feeling a burrito craving, this is the closest to my apartment. I usually get the super burrito. I like that they have spinach wraps here. The green salsa is pretty good, the red salsa is really spicy! The (free) chips are pretty greasy, but have a nice nutty crunch to them.
author: Sherry L.

description: They have 1 of the best prawn and carne aside dishes ever! :D and their rice and beans are just like authentic mexican homemade rice and beans. I would most definitely be coming back!
author: Rix L.

description:
Nothing really tastes good to me here.  Nothing tastes bad either.  It's just, "A-OK."

The prices are cheap, and the bathroom is clean, and there is no line (for the food or the bathroom).  So, I guess it covers the bases if you want something quick and fast.  

For those who wrote this place is similar to chipotle, you are all liars.  I hope Zeus thunderbolts your ass.  Chipotle has great cilantro rice, and well seasoned, tender chicken.  They both offer tofu.  For Taco Tuesday, the Iron Cactus offers $1 tacos.  They are just dry chicken with cilantro and no toppings, but not so bad for the price.

Good stop before the caltrain or a Giants game.
author: Allen T.

description: Very convenient for those that work in the area. As far as quality, it is mediocre and doesn't have a ton of flavor. But, if you want something quick and cheap, this is a terrific place.
author: Nick P.

description:
Thank you for the iron cactus.   I go at least twice a week for the tortilla 
soup with a side of grilled chicken.   I also love the homemadeTamales and the 
green salsa is by far the best in the city.  The service is fast and friendly.   You may not even know that one of the ladies serving you ACTUALLY MADE the tamales...no store bought food here!  When the line looks long during lunch rush, it moves quickly   The outside patio is a secret find.   Looking to cater a party.  Yes they cater the best Mexican food I've ever had at a party.   I easily give the iron cactus 4.5 stars and 
will keep going back for more!
author: Tiffany G.

description:
Very average Mexican food. Make sure to check the meats right there in front of you when you are ordering. If the pans looks low on food, chances are that you are going to get dried up, nasty stuff that you will not like - just warning you.

Highlights: Burrito bowls - you get more in the bowl than in the tortilla and it tends to be less dry.

Low Lights: Staff can be a bit clueless. The dude walks around with your food and will pass your table at least twice before finally dropping it off. They use numbers, but he always seems confused.

The food is OK, on the bland side, but you have plenty of hot sauce around to spice things up. Good spot for quick lunches, quicker than the sandwich bar at Safeway anyways :)
author: Sean H.

description:
The food is pretty good. They make great guacamole, and the portions are pretty large.

But the service is not great and the wait is longer than expected. 

Try the nachos!
author: Mason B.

description: My husband and I dine here every time we go to a ball game. Fast service,  reasonably priced and great food.  Recommended.
author: Cami C.

description:
Besides location, nothing is that great about Iron Cactus. Food is mediocre, service isn't the best, and the staff making your food can't understand English. 

I only go there when I'm too lazy to drive to the Mission, and because I only live a block away.
author: Kimberly L.
