description: Just love their food. Chips are always crunchy !! Green sauce is the best, aguas frescas is the best one in town!
author: Marcela M.

description:
To be honest, I stopped by because I was trying to get something better than Subway or some Safeway food before my train. Next time, I'll try and find something else... or just get a sandwich.

Very mediocre. It's the kind of place you need to be absolutely, stumbling over yourself drunk to enjoy your food. It feels more like a bar than a taqueria. I got a carnitas burrito--overpriced and dry. I had to douse it in salsa to make it taste somewhat decent. There are just too many amazing Mexican places in the Bay and SF in particular to settle for bland. So I probably won't be back (unless, of course, I'm stumbling over myself while drunk as aforementioned).
author: Justin E.

description: A good tofu burrito makes this a good spot for vegetarians. They also have some nice options like refried black beans that you don't see at many burrito spots. Some people reported small burritos, but I find the veggie super burrito to be a good size.
author: Kyle M.

description: oh boy. i'd read horrible reviews about this place and it did not disappoint. we went as a big work group for lunch. we preordered and my dish was the only one that didn't show up. she had to ask what i ordered and go check on it. i got my food about 5 min after everyone else. crispy taco plate, how hard can it be? better yet, how much reflux can it cause? the chicken chile verde was so greasy that i had a huge reaction to it even though i'd taken medication in anticipation of a greasy lunch. i literally had to leave the restaurant and walk off the acid upwelling in my esophagus. it was horrible. not only that but the chips had no flavor, the salsa was lame and the guacamole was the most unappealing color i've seen in a long time. would never go back. didn't want to go in the first place.
author: Tera K.

description:
Friendly service, average price..but I found the food to be really bland and boring...
Still waiting on a decent taqueria to open up nearby...
author: Mimi T.

description:
Agree with the sentiments in other reviews: it's a high priced yuppie Mexican restaurant in SF. But you know what? Sometimes the yuppieness pays off in strange ways. I found their carnitas tasty and made from good meat. I got them in the form of enchiladas - one carne asada, one al pastor, one carnitas, and it was the carnitas that really stood out to me as nicely cooked, couple of nice fatty pieces, and flavorful.

But I'm not mexican, feel free to completely ignore this post.

I will probably return here eventually when I need a really quick meal in the area, but I don't crave it that much. 3.5 stars...
author: Josh K.

description: The smallest super burrito I ever had, staff were friendly, nothing to write home about.
author: Toby H.

description:
So here's the thing, any new restaurant that's just opened is expected to have some sort of growing pains for the first month or so. Therefore I'll refrain from judging too harshly until a few more visits. 

Pros:
Great location
Outside seating
Inviting Ambiance - Very rustic 
Great happy hour specials (KEY)
Fresh ingredients - tex mex style

Cons: 
I waited 10 minutes for a salad...and I beat the rush by 20 minutes
Salad had more black beans than it did lettuce
Not super authentic like you may be used to in the Mission
Decent prices but not on the cheap side for sure

What I'm really excited about is their happy hour. Go time!

Happy Hour:
Half off Select Appetizers
Taco's $2;
House Red and White $5;
Draft Beer $3;
Monday to Friday 3-6pm;
Saturday & Sunday 4-6 pm
author: Kristy M.

description:
I work quite close to this place and have given it a very fair shot. 

It has given me food poisoning twice and the staff that buses the tables have physically harassed me with inappropriate touching numerous times when I've dined alone. 

I think tourists keep this terrible place in business. Please stop buying the hype and go somewhere else. 

Even though they are technically in the same location, neither of those things have happened to me when I've eaten at The Creamery - their staff have always been cool and their ingredients fresh. No guilt by proximity as far as my experience goes.
author: Stacie R.

description: The super burrito was average. I had to pour on the salsa to give it a chance at deliciousness. I then started to add in crushed tortilla chips for extra texture. It's not that their super burrito is horrible, it just tasted...well, average compared to some other places. My hunger was satisfied and I did finish said super burrito. The salsas were good though...three stars, a-ok.
author: Derek N.

description:
Please people look past these comments and take mine first hand. Between the setting and the freshness of the food I'd give it 6 stars in it's class. I'm a local here and after visiting some mission spots I can tell you about some interesting taco trucks and an 16th st. experience that would make you think twice about Mexican tonight.

1) full size pints of beer even during ball games
2) great surroundings
3) immaculate kitchen and everything is fresh.
4) free unlimited wi-fi
5) authentic friendly staff that tries
6) parking
7) big screen TV's 
8) reasonably priced considering the location.
9) great manager

I can understand if you didn't get it your way and even maybe you got crummy service in the hustle bustle of mid day lunch rush hour. I've always had a good meal here. Ivor the manager is always on site running the cash register and I'm certain if your order was not to your liking he'd be the first to make it right. 

Before you write another bad review please give it a second chance. And please follow up with better reviews.
author: Sandro T.

description:
The food isn't terrible but I wouldn't call it good either. It's close to the ballpark and has a lot of seating, so I can see how they can get away with serving below average food. 

The only reason to go here would be if you need to grab a quick meal before a Giants game but also need access to TVs to follow other games that are going on at the same time. Even then, I think you're better off walking a block or two to find another place around King or Townsend.
author: James Y.

description:
This place is right outside the Caltrain station, so I've stopped here for a post-commute burrito far more often than I should ever publicly admit. 

It's a pretty no-frills place, but the quality of food is definitely better than a Chipotle. It's also decently priced, the portions are giant, and they serve beer.  What more do you need?

Other perks:
-Most orders come with chips and salsa
-Tofu fillings available for my fellow vegetarians
-TVs inside playing whatever games are on
-Lots of seating
-Friendly staff

Overall, it's a casual and convenient place to stop by for a meal -- solo or with friends -- if you're in the area.
author: Rohini R.

description:
after a public transportation journey from Palo Alto to San Francisco, a girl gotta eat. i was craving something light but didnt want Subway from the SF Caltrain Station. I walked into the cafe next door and they said their kitchen just closed and suggested that I go to the Iron Cactus.

I quickly walked over there since i had another bus to catch. I ordered the Chicken Baby Burrito and expressed that I needed it done in 5 minutes and didnt want the guy making the order take forever. i kinda wanted a type of cow-meat but they all looked dry or like they have been sitting out there for a while. the pork looked super oily and heart-clogging. the burrito was nicely wrapped and comes with some tortilla chips which are super oily. the salsa definitely tastes good when you put it in the burrito making it less dry. the baby burrito may not be satisfying for the average person.

overall not bad, but nothing extravagant either.
author: Kathy W.

description:
Some people cite that the food here is not authentic.  Refer to my review of Gordo Taqueria for my thoughts on that.  With that said, my super tofu burrito was delish.  My philosophy with burritos and burgers is much like the Carls, Jr. slogan ("If it doesn't get all over the place, it doesn't belong in your face."), so I'm happy to report that the burrito was quite messy.  I almost couldn't take the picture fast enough before all the goodness started oozing out.

I also really liked the dining environment at Iron Cactus, with numerous pitchers of iced water at the ready, silverware and biodegradable plasticware, the long benches that accompany their tables, the squeeze bottle of guacamole on the tables in addition to the regular condiments, and the fact that you could walk through the hallway next door to The Creamery.

They also have happy hour (3-6PM) drink specials.

The customer service was decent in my opinion.

I guess the one criticism I have about Iron Cactus is that the prices are a bit higher than most, but considering the overall dining ambiance and the location, it makes sense.
author: Jenn C.

description:
This food is pretty  mehzers but the 2 stars are for convenience and speed. This place is good for groups. There are free chips. 

I have ordered salads, burritos, quesadillas and have not been too impressed. Slightly overpriced.
author: Adele Z.

description:
I wish I had time to write a better review, but I'm facing backward on Caltrain, hoping it will help me throw up.

There are nice TVs, which is almost a negative because there's no need for there to be TVs in a taqueria. And the place is clean.

But the service is slow. They overcharged me 50 cents. They forgot my friend's order so he had to order it again. They charge for chips, but they don't charge for chips. The men's bathroom doesn't lock.

They know they are near the train station and have little competition. So why be awesome? They get my empathy and also my wrath.
author: Joel E.

description:
I've ate here a couple times while waiting for the Caltrain, and I thought it was a pretty good place. I was surprised to see they only have 2 1/2 stars, probably wouldn't have eaten here if I had seen that! 

The only thing I have ever gotten at this place is their regular nachos. They don't have too much cheese, but they have a ton of black beans, chopped tomatoes and onions, and sliced jajalpenos. So, they're pretty healthy nachos. That might not be everyone's cup of tea, but I like the fact that they're not smothered in cheese. 

These nachos cost $4.50 for a huge plate of them, so it's a pretty good deal. But if you add meat, guacamole and sour cream and make your nachos super, the cost jumps to $8.75! I can see how people would be disappointed after ordering that, especially since I've heard the meat here wasn't very good. (I've never tried it since I always get the basic nachos).

I think most of the items on their menu are overpriced ($5.50 super taco? $8.50 for a burrito?!) But the regular nachos somehow seem to have avoided this overpricedness. If you stick with them you will leave happy and full.

It's not like I would go out of my way to eat here. But whenever I'm waiting for the Caltrain, this place is a convenient spot to fill my belly. When I'm sitting on their outdoor patio, eating nachos and drinking a beer, the ridiculous amount of time I have to wait for the next Caltrain usually goes by pretty quickly.

Also they have happy hour from 3-5pm. Beers are $3, and they have some pretty good ones. I just wish it went later than 5!
author: Laura L.

description:
The burrito I had at this place was close to disgusting. I thought it might get me sick- that's how bad it was.  I got a burrito in a spinach tortilla with just black beans, chicken and guac.  it came out smelly like old dank towels, I suspect it may have been the foil wrap or something.  They didn't drain the beans so my burrito was a sopping mess. UGH yuck. 

Never eat here.
author: Skye W.

description:
What kind of idiots put a sign outside advertising happy hour on game day then you get inside and there's a chicken scratched handwritten sign that says no happy hour on game days?! Just don't put the sign out on game days, retards.  And then when asked about it, they just dumbly look at you with no explanation.

Food was alright, nothing amazing. Overpriced w/o happy hour. Sangria was okay -- nothing amazing.
author: Latef X.

description:
I've been to Iron Cactus many times, when I lived in SOMA, when I visit the ballpark or just in the area.  I like tofu in my burrito and they are the only place I know of with a sauteed tofu option.

The food is less than decent. Edible.  I wouldn't say it's nasty or gross but it's not great or anything.

1 star because the service is just horrible.  Every time I go to Iron Cactus I order the same thing: baby veggie burrito with tofu and guacamole.  Every single time they charge me $1 extra for guacamole and they never put guacamole in it.  I seriously have to watch them like a hawk when they make my burrito and scream over the glass wall to make sure they put guac in.  I'm tired of paying extra and not getting what I ordered. 

Once when I told them there was no quacamole in my burrito, not only did they not make me a new one, they just plopped some guac in a to-go cup.  What the heck am I suppose to do with that? DIp my burrito in guac?

This past visit last week will be our last Iron Cactus visit.  My husband ordered a Chimichanga.  We waited for about 15 minutes and no food.  Everyone else who ordered after us (and spoke Spanish to the workers) got their food.  Then a lady comes up to us, after we waited over 15 minutes and tells us they cannot make a Chimichanga and that we need to order something else.  WTF? If you know you cannot make a chimichanga when we order, then say so.  Don't tell us to change our order after we've already waited for so long.  Oh and of course during that whole time we were waiting? No one was making my tofu burrito.  So total wait time? almost 1/2 an hour! They didn't even reduce the price of my husband's replacement burrito.  He was charged the chimichanga price.

WTH. This place is no bueno!
author: Terry D.

description: Most tasteless burrito I've ever eaten. Pico de gallo was so bad it was almost like they were trying to make it as bad as possible. Customer service horrific as the staff just stands there staring at you and doesn't let you know how the ordering process works. I wouldn't go here again under any circumstances and warn you to not waste your time or money on such an excuse for a taqueria.
author: Sherri G.

description:
The food here was bland.  A pint of Pacifico was $6.

However: the patio is great on a sunny day.  So the 4 star ambiance and the 2 star food makes this place a solid 3 stars.
author: Rocco B.

description: I came here with a few friends before a Giants game one Sunday afternoon. The interior is great: bright, large, and spacious. The place has a very casual atmosphere: you order right when you come in and the food arrives pretty quickly. I got 2 chicken tacos for $3.50 each, which is a great deal (or maybe I've just been living in Switzerland for too long), and they were pretty good. Not a bad place at all; if I were in the area again, I'd  go back again.
author: Sarah B.

description: I'd actually walked into The Creamery next door but they had already closed their kitchen so I went into the Iron Cactus. The chips were cold and stale and my super veggie burrito was less than delicious. It was bland and the veggie mixture just wasn't good. Who puts giant coin-cut carrots in a burrito? That just ruins the texture.
author: Rowena L.

description:
Now that I work in the SOMA neighbourhood, I've been looking for places to have lunch or grab a bite before/after work and since I love Mexican food, I figured I'd try out The Iron Cactus.

Came during lunch hour and it was fairly empty, probably due to the pounding rain outside. The menu was pretty expansive and even included a tofu option for those who want to enjoy a burrito without meat. I love meat, but it's great that the option is there.

I ordered a super burrito with carne asada, no guac and made spicy. For $7, I was pretty pleased. The burrito came out in decent time and it tasted great, although I was a bit irked out when I bit into the mush of super cold sour cream and rice and then bit into hefty chunks of fresh off the grill carne asada. I'm REALLY big about how well ingredients are mixed in a burrito. But overall, I enjoyed it thoroughly and I'm sure I'll be back.
author: Trav M.

description:
Hmm...I don't think this place is atrocious like some Yelpers, but I don't think I'll be back if I'm craving Mexican food.  I got the super veggie burrito with tofu which was just ok.  A couple of downsides:

1.  I asked for a bowl but was given a burrito instead.
2.  I asked for spicy salsa inside, which was mild at best.
3.  The red salsa at the "salsa bar" had a weird honey taste which I didn't care for.
4.  I paid for the super variety but hardly got any guac and sour cream in my burrito.

The upsides:
1.  Good green salsa - yummy in fact.
2.  Chips were fresher than Taco Bell's.

In this case, there were too many downsides and hence the (2.5) star review. Like I said, I probably won't be back.
author: Nina V.

description:
Iron Catfood is a better name. 

Food was good the first time we went (about 2 weeks after it opened), went back twice a couple weeks later and it was awful. Super Burrito had shrunk about 3 inches in size and I needed a magnify glass to find the meat.  

This place makes Taco Bell look like a Michelin star restaurant.
author: Matt Z.

description:
Absolutely fantastic venue (and catering!) for a party.  Am I the only one who didn't know about this until my bridesmaid randomly thought to call and ask???  Seriously, throw your bash here and you'll get to meet the nicest owner with a lovely Scottish accent AND have delicious catering in a cute backyard you can pretend is yours for a day.

I had my bridal shower here recently and the backyard was perfect; also WAY more affordable than some of the other probably better-known venues we'd seen around the city.  The long wood table setup was ideal for our group of about 22 girls and for indulging in our rustic-chic decorating urges.  They can provide table linens, but we opted to bring a linen table runner with succulent plants running along the table.  We had a gift table/area in the back.  I.C. even threw in some rare sunshine for free that day.

For beverages, Iron Cactus provided red and white sangrias, mimosas, fresh orange juice, a wide array of red and white wines for guests to choose from.  They have passed hors d'oeuvres of prosciutto wrapped figs with balsamic reduction, and vegetable crostinis with carmelized onions (meat optional).  Buffet lunch was sauteed beef strips with herbs and shallots, colorful sauteed veggies of the day, a pasta primavera, spicy shrimp, and a fresh arugula/blood orange salad with cheese.  

I just made myself hungry, so I'm going to get some food now.  Will post some pics here too.
author: Julie C.

description: Horrible service! My first time at this establishment, and I was asked to leave my table so they could sit a larger party. I was waiting on a friend to arrive and there were no other tables in the restaurant. I explained that I found it rude to ask a customer to move that had already paid for something at the restaurant. The gentleman who asked me to move replied, "I'm just doing my job." So your job is to be rude an inconvenience someone who already paid to use your establishment? I won't be going back. Worst service in San Francisco. I wish there were a way to give zero or negative stars.
author: Bradley V.

description: I didn't actually get to eat my burrito, because despite asking twice about cilantro then ordering my burrito to go with NO cilantro, I found it stuffed with the inedible weed.  My co-worker finished his burrito and also said, "Well, that was unsatisfying and had no flavor."  I guess I didn't miss much, but doesn't change that I ended up with no lunch today.  Thanks a lot, Iron Cactus.
author: Stephen G.

description:
I really want to like this place because its ambiance is basically perfect for a Mexican non-taqueria, non-restaurant.  But its food?  Please.  Seriously, if you're going to put that many things on the menu board, you need to make them good.  They don't need to be the best I've ever had, but they should be decent.

I'll give it another try, mostly because my dad likes it so much, but I'm sure there's better Mexican food in the neighborhood.  It's sad, too, because the place is so inviting.
author: John S.

description: Awful burrito. Bad rice with no seasoning and too much liquid. Wouldn't even let me sub guac for tofu. The tofu costs more!
author: Benjamin S.

description:
Iron Cactus is a una gran adición al vecindario (great addition to the neighborhood).

Conveniently located within a block of CalTrain, Safeway, and ATT Park, Iron Cactus brings good, although gringo-ized Mexican food to South Beach.  The unassuming exterior belies the soaring ceilings and brick walls inside:  while not exactly "cozy," the space is homey - warm, inviting, and clean.

Let's get it straight:  Iron Cactus is not competing with dive Mexican places in The Mission.  Situated in South Beach, it caters to more refined tastes than the traditional taqueria at 16th and Mission.  Yes, the offerings may not be as spicy as El Farolito or Pancho Villa, but they are also not as greasy, nor as dangerous to your health - organic and sustainable where possible, the establishment uses ingredients that won't kill you.

The menu sticks to the basics:  burritos, tacos, quesadillas, etc.  There is nothing inventive here, and it is just as well.  In a setting such as this, diners are looking for tried and true favorites, not foamed creations from Ferran Adrià from El Bulli.

Patrons cannot go wrong with any of the burritos, quesadillas, or salads from Iron Cactus:   as in any Mexican restaurant worth its salt, you choose your meat, choose your tortilla, choose your beans, and choose your level of spiciness.  The result is pure Americanized, Mexican goodness.  Yes, not as spicy as some. Yes, not as greasy as some.  Yes, not as Hispanic as some.  But, hey, this is South Beach, not The Mission.

A burrito de pollo asado was quite tasty.  Yes, even though ordered "picante," it could have been spicier, it was still good.  Chicken Caesar was great:  crispy Romaine lettuce, spicy pollo asado, and light dressing.  Quesadilla de camarones tipped the tabnels at "awesome" - lots of shrimp, good cheese to shrimp ratio, not overcooked. 

Happy hours rock:  cheap beer and cheap tacos. Need I say more?

Service es muy bueno:  everyone is polite, service-oriented, and just all around nice.  Drinks consists of sodas, beers (both by the bottle and on tap), and some wines.

Want greasy, cheap Mexican food?  Go to The Mission.  Want good, healthy Mexican food that is convenient to where real people live, work, and commute, go to Iron Cactus.
author: CJ G.

description:
This place is just a block away and other than Victor's it's the only Taqueria type place in the area within walking distance. I've been here a few times since they opened and I've noticed some improvement. More organized, better ways to serve the salsa but they can still improve what they're serving.

This place does satisfy my craving - I enjoy the carne asada tacos but they are a bit overpriced. BUT the salsa could use some definite work (although I'm spoilt by the salsa from Pancho Villa) and actually have more depth in the flavor. I'd recommend watching the portions a bit ... can save money and also make it easier for the patrons to eat. There's too much on the tacos when I get them and I can't pick it up and have to break it up to eat it without looking completely uncoordinated.
author: Dalia M.

description:
Wow. Maybe I have just had a bad week of eating out, but coming to the Iron Cactus for lunch really resonated with me in a poor fashion. I work in SOMA so coming here was moreso a decision of convenience than of desire to try their food. 

First of all, it is like the pricey version of Chipotle - they have a rice/beans/proteins/veggies/sauces bar that is out for hours... but $15 for a chimichanga that was subpar? No thank you. The ambiance is cool for watching sports - take note - they have wooden benches, but the prices they charge are ludicrous for mediocre Mexican. I am a SoCal native, so I have been raised on authentic Mexican food my whole life - and not only does this lack authenticity, it lacks flavor, period.

Funny thing is, their food comes out fast (probably because it's been sitting behind the counter waiting for the hungry lunch crowd), but LUKEWARM! Their service is really lackluster, and to add insult to injury, they have a TIP JAR - bad service + feeling entitled to tips??? Sorry Charlie.

I would much rather go to the Mission, order a delicious, reasonably priced burrito and give them a tip. Not only would I receive paramount service, but I'm sure the food would actually taste good. 

I may go back one more time since I work in the area, and am keen on second chances, but definitely not a place I would recommend. It is a poor reflection of what the city of San Francisco has to offer in regards to culinary experiences. Come her if you have low expectations, and really need to eat beans that taste like they came out of a refried beans can.
author: Tammy H.

description:
We (my husband and I) came here a couple weeks ago on our quest to try 52 new places in 52 weeks. 

Meh. I've experienced better. Yelp!- if you can't say it better, don't, right?
author: Melissa N.

description:
I wait for the bus in the morning across the street from Iron Cactus.  For months I saw construction going on and wondered what would appear.  Then one day construction finished and Iron Cactus appeared.  

I finally got to try it out last week when a friend wanted to grab a quick bite.  Food is not great, but not terrible either.  For the price, worth going for something quick and easy.  It's nice that they serve alcohol as well, so you can have a nice cold beer with your burrito.

I found the staff friendly and service was quick.  Didn't have the issues some others here had with slow service.
author: Wayne L.

description:
The food is good, but not great.   However, they are very quick and have a ton of variety.  Great place to eat if you are about to catch the Caltrain or are heading to ATT park for a game.   

They have an outdoor patio that is almost hidden if you dont realize it.   Walk past the hallway with the bathrooms to access.
author: Jason B.

description:
Wow. The Iron Cactus has resorted to purporting that they are worthy of a Yelp! sticker. Yep. I saw it with my own eyes. While walking past this nasty-faux-burrito-making establishment, I noticed the bright Yelp! sticker on their window. Yes, the Yelp! sticker that indicates this establishment has an AVERAGE of 4 stars. The sticker that says this place is loved by tons of Yelpers. What's the problem? El problemo is that Iron Cactus NEVER had an average of 4 stars! I don't think they ever had an average of 3 stars! LOOK at their average! Barely above a 2! 
While I'm not one to complain about restaurants SHILLING or paying off "patrons" to write glowing reviews about their establishment, this just made me disgusted. You're lying to people by saying this place is loved. And THAT is just no bueno.
Yelp!, you better not be passing out those stickers like candy on Halloween. Just sayin...
author: A A.

description: I was looking at the menu and had 3 people come up and ask me if I was ready yet but I was literally still standing next to the door and said I wasn't ready yet, I was annoyed but I'm sure most people would think that it was good service? Idk.. Any way when I was ready to order she seemed already annoyed with me.. Probably cause I took too long or something.. Food. The menu looked good with a lot of tasty options (I'm a big fan of Mexican food) I ordered carnitas enchiladas plate. Eh. Somehow the carnitas were extremely dry even though they were covered in sauce.. And the sauce oddly really sweet. I did not like. Beans and rice ok. Beans taste like canned.. But I like canned refried haha so.. Anyways the pluses: cokes in the glass battle sidral Mundet apple soda in the glass bottle good looking restaurant beers on tap.. I probably won't come back.. Eh maybe for happy hour.
author: Carlie B.

description:
Everything looks great while you in line looking at the various meats, beans and veggies. However, without fail, every time I've gotten my food to-go, it's a big old mess. 

The Grilled chicken salad: 
1) Sits in a bed of water - no bueno, at least you know the lettuce is clean.
2) "Grilled chicken" - Seasoned chicken that sits in a food warmer
3) "Roasted Corn" - corn out of a can
4) "Avocados" - sure they're there...all 3 slivers of them. 

+1* for the Organic/Sustainable meats
+1* for the overall ambiance

I'm sure i'll be back since I work in the area - but i'll probably preface with "extra dry lettuce" please.
author: Rana A.

description:
Service is awkward, slow as molasses, and incoherent.

However if you were to come to the Iron Cactus, the saving grace of this place is the Mexican Chicken Salad. It isn't gourmet food, but it's definitely edible and the dressing isn't terrible and you can always heap on the spicy green stuff (located in one of the two jars on each table at the Iron Cactus).
author: Angie C.

description: Quantity, not quality. The food is only okay but they give you a lot. Got the fish taco plate and I thought it was overpriced ($12) for meh tasting Mexican food. I won't be coming back unless I get a super Mexican food craving and no one else in the area is open.
author: Diana F.

description:
Way too overpriced for the quality of food you get (which is crap). I live near the Mission where the burritos and Mexican food are the tops in SF for both taste and price. But after going to Iron Cactus, I feel so ripped off. 

I'm the type of person that eats LOTS of food and loves almost everything but I never thought I would go somewhere where I couldn't finish the rest of a burrito because it was that terrible. I got an al pastor super burrito and came to find nearly ZERO meat in it, the black beans overwhelmed it and the rice and sour cream/guac just turned to mush. And they added pineapple in it (WTF). The burrito couldnt hold itself together.

This was my 3rd time coming here, mostly because I live within a block from the place. But will def never spend my money here again unless its for $1 tacos and beer happy hour.
author: Matt A.

description:
I have no experience with the food at this place, but I sampled their sangria during happy hour. Stepped in as I waited for the next CalTrain, and I gotta say the #1 thing this place has going for it is proximity to the station!

Decent prices, so-so sangria, but I did enjoy the complementary chips and salsa!
author: Gwen T.

description:
I'm surprised that a 2-star "taqueria" has a place in SF, but that part of SOMA does repel good cheap eats.  The guacamole was watery because it was diluted with beefsteak tomatoes.  Fish in the fish tacos was overcooked and dry.  

If you're looking for lunch-time mexican, head down Townsend to Victor's.  Unfortunately they're not open in the evening.
author: seema s.

description:
Me: I'd like to have the Sopes Plate please.
Them: We do not have Sopes now
Me: OK, I'd like to have the Cactus Combo then.
Them: OK, which meat do you want in your tamale?
Me: Pork please
Them: We only have chicken.
Me: OK, I'll have that and pork in my hard taco then
Them: You also want a taco?
Me: I think the Combo comes with one
Them: Oh OK
Me: Yes, and can you make that a hard taco please?
Them: The crispy?
Me: Yes the crispy.
Them: That also comes with a flauta you know.
Me: I see that, what type?
Them: Just chicken.
Me: OK.

The plate was OK, the tamale being the best part. My friend's Pastor was a bit dry but flavorful, the garlic shrimp was juicy (but tasted like Chinese food), definitely the best item we had. The portions were about right but definitely pricey for Mexican, about $14/person.

It's a toss up. Being used to the food in northern Mexico (i.e. LA) for 6 years, I cannot justify the price with the quality. But if I wanted Mexican and didn't want to have to haul to Mission,  this place will get you by.
author: Snuffles B.

description:
This place strives for mediocrity, and yet somehow misses the mark.

Strictly for the commuter and ballpark crowd:  The employees seem to have crowd fatigue, even when it isn't crowded.  The food reflects that same lack of enthusiasm.  It isn't horrible, just very, very bland.  

If you're on your way somewhere, and you have to grab a bite, you might as well stop here, but if you're hungry for Mexican food, keep going.
author: B A.

description:
My husband and I chose Iron Cactus purely on the basis that he wanted Mexican and most of the other Mission Bay-area joints were closed on Sunday.  The 2.5 average on Yelp should've warned me.  My order was taken at the counter by an extremely unfriendly woman.  As a first-timer, I asked her how spicy the "spicy" salsa was, since the only choices for my burrito were mild and spicy.  I meant... is this going to blow my head off, or is it just a nice spicy kick?  She responded "spicy."  Thanks, very helpful.

FYI - I could barely taste the salsa in my burrito, so I think it's safe to say the spicy is maybe a 2/5 on the spicy scale.

I ordered a super burrito (comes with meat, beans, cheese, guac, and sour cream) with carne asada, black beans, and spicy salsa.  Maybe I just chose a bad combination, but it was very very bland.  I left about half on my plate.  We also got chips and salsa - chips weren't warm - it looked liked they'd been sitting out forever.

The lady continued to be rude to us as we tried to figure out when/how you pay and get drinks.

My husband thought his burrito was ok, but if I have any say in it I won't be going back.
author: Erin B.

description:
So I came here looking to spend about 4 bucks for a quick bite to eat, but was disappointed to see that it was going to cost me $3.50 + tax for one lonely taco. I immediately wrote this place off as an overpriced, overambitious Cali-Mexican place that overcharges because of its prime location. HOWEVER, the person taking orders muttered my two favorite words in the English language...Happy Hour.

Happy Hour 3-6 every day: huge tacos for $2, 20oz beer for $3, appetizers for $3. The beer selection is pretty legit: I recall Sam Adams, Stella Artois, Anchor Steam, Fat Tire and Sierra Nevada. I went for a carne asada taco with spicy salsa and an al pastor taco with mild salsa. Grand total: $4.65 with tax. The cashier was very friendly, even making a point to with me happy holidays. He did inform me, however, that chips are not included with my order.

But anyway, they brought out my tacos, and I was blown away. They are HUGE. I'd say the tacos here are between 1/3 and 2/5 the way to being a normal-sized burrito. They have all the burrito necessities: rice, beans, meat, sour cream and salsa (another review says you can get lettuce for no extra charge...I'll definitely hit that up next time). They're hard to eat as tacos because of the sheer amount of rice, beans and meat, so I got a fork and got to work.

The carne asada and al pastor were both very tasty. Sure, the carne asada was not 100% consistent across the board, and when I first tasted it I couldn't taste barely anything, but when I focused and looked for the taste, I found it and I liked it. The al pastor was even better; nice mix of spices, tender, consistent...I really enjoyed eating it.

The salsa here is tasty, but in no way is it spicy. The mild is a joke, and the 'hot' salsa is what mild salsa would be at a real Mexican place. I'm really confused as to these people who say they eat spicy food but thought this place was too spicy. The spiciest thing they have is the green salsa they have on the tables, which is somewhere between mild and hot at a real Mexican place. I don't get it.

Self-serve water is a huge plus. 'Nuff said.

The take-away: the happy hour here is great. Two huge tacos and a 20oz beer for $7? If I'm ever at the office late, this is gonna be one of my go-to places.
author: Geoff L.

description:
We asked Iron Cactus to cater a work event last night and I couldn't be more pleased. The food was great, the servers kind and the catering contact person is phenomenal.

We had build your own tacos, chips, churros and mexican cookies. Everything was delicious. I'm a vegetarian so I can only attest to the rice, beans, sour cream and guacamole. I also thought the churros were excellent. Our guests were very happy with the food as well. Many remarked that they did not expect the food to be so good at the event.

I will definitely be going there for lunch or dinner and if I need Mexican catering again they will be at the top of my list!
author: Jeanette L.

description:
This place has really fallen off over the last six months. I used to enjoy their good quality ingredients and portion size (burrito bowls) - but lately, the quality of ingredients and preparation is shoddy at best. Add in their move to 'children' portions and I've taken my business elsewhere.

Haven't noticed the owner/manager around lately, but he used to keep the focus on the food/customer and not make it solely about the $$$.

I'm rooting for a return to glory.
author: Trevor F.

description:
Food - 3 stars
Pet Friendly - 5 stars

I had the chicken salad and hubby had the chicken mole with chips and guacamole for an appetizer.  Service was fast; food was decent; and, dogs are welcomed on the back patio which does have heaters (yay!).

The only con is that there's nothing really memorable about our meals - everything was just ok.  I'd certainly go back if I wanted Mexican food on our walk to/from the Mission Bay dog park.
author: Kim W.

description: Ate here to kill some time before a train. Food menu fairly extensive as is the number of beers on draught. Recommend the Nachos which were nice wasn't convinced by the service
author: Alan K.

description:
Not coming back.  I'd select zero stars, but yelp requires at least one. 

We live about 2 blocks away and figured we'd give it a go.  We checked out the website and saw that we could order online, so we did.  The site said we could pick up our food at 8:46pm.  We showed up at 8:45 and were told that our internet order never showed up.  Apparently they are faxed to the restaurant and that process hasn't been working for 2 days.  Fail.

The cashier was apologetic and took our order: two burritos, no cheese, no sour cream on either, to go.  They showed up quickly on plates. No problem. Easy put them in bags to take home.  

We left at around 8:55, got home and opened the burritos at 9:02pm only to find that  one had both cheese & sour cream.  Huge FAIL. (cheese has been known to put me in the hospital) We only live about 4 minutes away so we called the restaurant to see if they could re-make the 2nd burrito.  We were told that they have already thrown out all of their food.  If a restaurant closes at 9pm they have all of their food thrown out by 9:02?  Really?  

The cashier on the phone did offer to refund our money, but that doesn't fix our burrito fix! 

As a side note, the burrito that was made properly was pretty lackluster.  Not coming back.  Except to get our money back.
author: David B.

description:
I work close to this The Iron Cactus so I thought I would try it out early in the lunch hour as this place always has a long line. So naturally I was intrigued.

I must say that there is much better mexican food than this place has to offer.  

First, the prices are inflated. The women taking the order was not very friendly and neither was the cashier. I spoke Spanish to them both as they were both latina and they did not even say one word back to me.

I will take my business to Victor's in the future where greetings of GUAPO welcome me with a smile.
author: Ernesto C.

description:
Good location.  Seating is good with a rustic feel.  Food, however, is a skip.

super carnitas burrito - w/ guacamole, cheese & sour cream - $8.75 - asked for extra spicy, no spice at all - not carnitas but chicken.  they were not even busy, how do they screw that up?

flauta appetizer - $5 - served with salsa and lettuce - not fresh, it was so chewy and with barely any filling even hubby skipped it. 

horchata - best of the evening.

Next.
author: Gloria H.

description:
I usually hit up The Iron Cactus is near my apartment and so I hit it up whenever I'm too lazy to drive and not wanting to cook in. It's decent Mexican and probably not much better than Taco Bell. I usually have their Prawn Quesadilla or Chicken Quesadilla which are both pretty decent. Their Super Nacho is totally disappointing to me because it's not dripping with cheese and other necessary ingredients to make it a "Super Nacho" the way it's shown on the menu. 

I think it's actually gotten a bit pricier from when they originally opened too.
author: Soozie H.

description:
Where to begin? I wish this place was good. I live right by it. I would go there a lot. But unfortunately everything we tried on the menu was at best bland and at worst gross. Additionally everything was cold. I cannot fathom anyone going back a second time. 

On a positive note the staff was very friendly.
author: Knickerbocker R.

description: I had my birthday catered from here. Had a good, clear, and concise planning meeting with the owner, and I was assured a good experience. On party day, the staff was on time, helped set up the party, provided all the materials. Food was good, and everybody was satisfied. Since then, when I go into the restaurant, the owner recognizes me and always gives me a friendly hello. Although I don't live in the area anymore, I would recommend this place if you have a burrito craving or if you just want a party catered!
author: Tim w.

description:
This place sucks.

The food quality is mediocre at best and the prices are way too high. There are much better Mexican places within a 1-2 block radius (ie, Chavo's).

On top of that, the cashier ripped me off last time and insisted that I paid with a $10 when I knew I paid with a $20. I decided not to push the issue too much.

Frankly, I am baffled that this place is still in business.
author: Eugene A.

description: Stopped here for a quick bite before taking Caltrain on June 16, 2013. Paid with my credit card. Today noticed that I was charged twice - once for the amount without the tip, and once for the amount with the tip. Called Citi to dispute, and was told that I can only dispute the amount without the tip because I actually authorized the tip. I guess it is only fair to pay somebody for stealing from me!
author: Olga N.

description:
Stick to the salads

As far as the tacos, I think they buy the tortillas at safeway. That is really all that comes to my mind.

The burritos are nuked before being served and the chicken tends to be dry.  Though if you do give the Cactus a try and absoulutely need a burrito, order the wet burrito, as the sauce adds some flavor.  

The prices are ridiculous considering the food quality. They do use Niman ranch meats which are of a good quality, but unfortunately good ingredients do not always result in good food.

On the brighter side

The salad with chicken or shrimp (or a combination of the two for a slight up-charge) is really good though I wish the house dressing exuded a little more flavor.  Make sure you ask for an extra side of dressing and add a little salsa to it. Overall it is a nice combination of lettuce, hot peppers, onion, and corn possessing nice flavors and textures.

But If you want flavorful Mexican Food go to the el toyonese truck at best buy. 

The Fish=Wisdom. Wisdom=The Fish
author: Fish E.

description: Cool ambiance, but that's about it. Guacamole was soupy, the salsa was runny and the $11 salad was worth $5.
author: Ted T.

description:
came here the other day for some grub and i left pretty disappointed...

first of all...granted, i know that this place is located in SOMA, and thus everything is a bit overpriced BUT that doesnt mean the burrito should be 10 bucks...thats just borderline evil.  

oh, and there is nothing "super" about their "super burrito"...its tiny...but still bursting with rice and beans...very little meat...very sad, sad burrito...one of the worst if you ask me...

i also ordered up a enchilada plate...which by the way they RAN OUT OF...how the heck do you run out of enchiladas? enchiladas is just meat and cheese wrapped in a tortillas and topped with enchilada sauce...a taqueria running out of enchiladas is the same as mcdonalds running out of double cheeseburgers...i mean...just throw 2 cheeseburgers together and you have yourself a double cheeseburger right? 

being that you have to pay before they start making stuff, they informed me 15 minutes AFTER i had paid...they wouldnt give me my money back but instead they told me to order anything else, even if it was more expensive....i asked for the garlic prawns as that was the most expensive thing on the menu...then proceeded to eat 2 of them as they tasted old...

on a side note...their corn tortillas are good.

never coming back to eat food here ever again. rather walk 4 miles in the rain to the mission and eat off a street cart....
author: Kyu L.

description:
I went to Iron Cactus on a regular Saturday evening, around 6:30pm.  It was my second or third time there, and by far the busiest.
Let's talk about the wait.  25 minutes  before they even took our order.  The rude guy with the accent completed the transaction without looking at me, but more about him later.
The food was awful! $9.75 for a shitty Super Burrito!  WTF!

After waiting for another 20 minutes before our food came, we decided to go home as it was crowded and loud in there.  I ask the jerk with the accent behind the counter to change my order to go, and the asshole says "TOO LATE YOU SHOULD HAVE ORDERED IT THAT WAY"  I am befuddled and walk away.

Burritos finally came, we asked for a carton packed it and bounced.  The carne asada burrito had bones and fat in the meat and was flavorless and bland.  It came out cold and tasted like shit.

F this place.  I am telling everyone I know to never set foot in that shithole.  I'm looking forward to the day when it's gone and replaced by another vacant lot in Soma.
author: Anuj K.

description:
As this place is within spitting distance from where I live and I pass it every day on the way to and from work, I was hoping that this would be a good source of reliable Mexican food. I'm rarely as happy as when I am eating a good burrito. 

It has quite the unappealing atmosphere. You feel rushed to order, despite a rather lengthy menu to choose from. Your order is taken by people who really don't seem to care about your food. Then you pay and (if you are getting the food to go) have to hang out rather awkwardly among the other diners while waiting for your food, which seems to take a long time for a basic burrito assembly line. 

The burrito itself was a little disappointing. Due to the proximity, I've eaten here twice, and both times it was disappointing. I actually didn't finish the second one, and that almost never happens. I would have loved to get a weekly burrito here, but I definitely won't be going back.
author: Scott C.

description:
This place is what 3 stars is...A-OK!

Only been here a few times and all times have had an ok experience. My first time there was Opening Day this year. My friend and I ended up not getting tickets and decided to look for a place to watch. Well...she wasn't 21 yet so we stumbled on this place. I liked it as soon as I walked in because you could actually hear the game. They didn't have music playing.

The food was ok...but amazing but it was not bad. They also have a good variety of drinks and their sangria is yummy, yet I've had better. 

What has me coming back is the proximity to the 4th & King caltrain station. Every missed  train or get to the station early and just so happens that there's a Giants game?! Iron Cactus is the place to go!

I would give it more stars if the food and ambiance was better. They need to get more people in so it can be more fun during game days.
author: Belem R.

description:
It's my first time here and I'm not coming back.  I would go down 3rd Street and go to The New Spot for much better food.

I ordered the 2 chicken tamale appetizer since I was not that hungry.  The tamale was bland and super hot (temperature). I also ordered the horchata and it was already preglassed with a few ice cubes in it already.

Spend a train ride down to 3rd and 20th Streets and head to The New Spot.
author: Allen C.

description:
BORING. Is it REALLY that hard to make a decent, flavorful burrito? Dropped in after work on my way home, half expecting something decent as the spot always seems to have at leastt a little activity. I mean, I get it. It's near Caltrain and ATT Park and it's clearly trying to siphon off customers from both venues -- definitely not a destination in and of itself. So what the hell, I was hungry and curious.

Smelled pretty good but as I approached the sneeze shield I saw what could only be described as GROSS hunks of dried out meat sitting in warming trays. Relax, I thought. Maybe they will throw it on the grill for a few seconds but nope, right into the burrito. Maybe it's just so good and flavorful I should treat it like chili, also not high in the looks department but damn good. Ordered, paid ($7.82 for a barebones "regular" burrito) and thought about a beer but when the dude rang up a Corona at $4.50 I said "no thanks." 

Walked the half block to my house and ... remember the dried crusty meat? Still in the burrito and completely flat and tasteless. The tortilla was rough and dry (not chewy and moist), the rice a little hard and clearly sitting out since lunch, and the "spicy" salsa bland and boring. Damn this burrito was useless and silly. I am staring at 90 percent of it in my trashcan pissed that I have to go out and get some real food. Won't be coming back ... expect maybe on Tuesday night for $2.00 Coronas and $1.00 tacos. Like "Heroes" when it started fumbling mid second season, I'll give it one more chance ... I really want to find a decent burrito experience by my crib.

Come on Iron Cactus, don't be afraid to throw out food at 8pm that's been sitting out since lunch. Seriously. One more chance!
author: Steven H.

description:
For the gripers who say that there is cheaper food in the area, sure but not with a HUGE commitment to sustainablity! This place sports Niman ranch meat, local produce and very good working conditions. I am a chef and I can see, feel and taste the quality and value of this place. 
For a small amount more, you get food that is super fresh, served with a smile and sustainable. Also, it is VERY claen.

I love the griper who was mad that when he spoke Spanish, he did not get a warm response, that really made me laugh! 

I love it here and come for a great, affordable lunch in a top notch atmosphere every time I come to do radio at Clear Channel. 

and the coffee and pastries next door are excellent!
author: Rachelle B.

description:
Pluses: large dining area. Minuses: Food, pricing.

So Iron Cactus does have one thing going for it, it's a large venue with plenty of seating for a big group lunch. On the other hand, their food is actually less spicy than the Mexican food at Taco Bell. But will cost you much more. We joked that the Irish-accented cashier was the owner, because the food is probably what Mexican restaurants located in Dublin serve people -- but maybe it's true and she really is the owner! If so, PLEASE switch to serving corned beef.
author: Ian G.

description: Okay, it's been a couple of months since I've been in this place, but totally forgot to do my review.  Maybe because it wasn't too memorable, don't know.  I came here with 5 others and got their garlic prawns plate and it was pretty all right.  The prawns were grilled with mushrooms and came with rice, beans, and a salad, all for about $12.  If hungry, definitely load up on the chips & salsa.  Nothing to write home about really, but would come here again...if someone else came with me.
author: Emy B.

description:
Slow, slow, slow.  Consistently slow.

Why does it take 10 minutes for them to deliver a bowl of tortilla soup when there's hardly anyone in there?

You take your ladel, plop some soup into a bowl, and throw in some tortilla strips.

Seriously.
author: Kevin B.

description: This place sucked. My food was two hours late. When I got it it wasn't even good. The service was slow. The dj played old nasty songs that nobody listens too. Overall don't come here.
author: Sierra M.

description:
Bottom line:  decent enough food, but one of the worst values I've yet seen in SF.  

Stopped in here for lunch, and was suitably disappointed.  This was one of the more expensive burritos I've seen in the city, yet was one of the smallest and least filling.  The carne asada did not taste grilled at all.  They also take your order and then reappear with a burrito after a while.  I saw they were overwhelming the burritos with rice, so I asked for a little bit of rice instead.  There was none in there at all.  Just let me direct the assembly of my burrito so that it comes out how I want it.

Salsa bar was minimal, but decent.  Chips that came with the burrito were probably the most well done part of the meal.  No need to go back to this one.  If the food had been as bad as the rest of the experience, this would be an easy single-star review.  That it tasted good, even though it was poorly executed, upped it to a second star.
author: Adam G.

description:
On my way home from golf and thought about having some mexican. I've driven by Iron Cactus several times and it's in my hood, so could get it and take it to go.  Parking on the street, right in front, so let's give it a try.

Big menu board when you enter.  Lots of choices.  I only had 11 minutes of parking so no long decisions.  I ordered the Burrito with steak, and a side of quacamole.  The lady took my order down and handed me a receipt to take to the cashier.

Turns out she didn't give me a side of guacamole.  She gave me a small appetizer portion, which was $6.50.  I asked the lady to take it off, but now she conveniently doesn't speak English and I had a horrible time explaining to her that I wanted a side of guac, which was only $1.50.  After 2 minutes, I relented and paid for this as she didn't know how to take it off the bill!  A burrito, chips, salsa and guac and a can of coke for $16.60.

Food in hand, I was frustrated and left and thought maybe the guac, chips and salsa, along with my burrito, would be OK.  I got it home and opened the box which had the chips, salsa and guac.  It was cold, like it had come out of a refrigerator.  The guac was some green concoction that I'd buy in a box at Safeway, not what I'd expect from a mexican restaurant.  The chips tasted day-old, and who likes cold chips?  Not me.  Presentation sucked too, as the guacamole and salsa was splattered all over the chips in the box.

The burrito.... who has a burrito without cheese?  Stupid me for assuming a burrito will have cheese. It had lots and lots of rice, and a paltry amount of beef.  I ate it, but I'd barely call it food.

In closing, save your money and go to taco bell, because you'll get better mexican food there.  Don't go to Iron Cactus.  The food is horrible!  If I could give negative stars, I would.
author: Todd M.

description: I have to admit that I was disappointed. I got the super burrito al pastor and it was below what I would consider average. It was OK and that was all. It didn't have that extra umpf that you're expecting from a good Mexican resturaunt.
author: Blake Y.

description: The food was decent. Nothing special about it. But what was not ok: they sell soda in cans or bottles and there is NO refill and the soda is relatively expensive compared to other locations.
author: Christopher S.

description:
I came here on Tuesday for the $1 tacos and $2 Corona, which is definitely an excellent deal. Adding a side of rice and beans for a couple bucks makes a complete meal.

There is ample seating (inside and out) and the food was decent, though the carnitas was a bit dry. The service was friendly and efficient, even with the baseball game rush..

I must say that I'm surprised how popular this place was given the low rating. Close proximity to the ballpark and train is a plus.
author: George B.

description: I'm stuck going here sometimes because it's the only sit-down Mexican spot near my office, and I'm a glutton for punishment. But, oh, is it ever bad. The service is poor, and the staff acts like they couldn't care less whether or not they get your business. The food itself is way over-priced and mediocre - and I swear, it's the weirdest-tasting 'chicken' I've ever tasted, even smothered in cheese and sauce.
author: Lady Y.

description:
I really enjoy the Iron Cactus.  The burritos may not be as "authentic" as the ones you'd find in the Mission, but they are still tasty.  I appreciate that they are open relatively late and on weekends (the other inexpensive Mexican options in SOMA tend to closer early and not be open at all on weekends...).

The burritos are good, the service is fast, and the owner is nice.  I hope they make it and are open for a long time.
author: Ben B.

description:
I have low expectations for mexican food -- give me food, salsa, and napkins. We got 1.5/3.

It was super slow (mid afternoon, weekend), with maybe a 1/2 dozen people in the whole place. It still took what felt like 10 minutes to take our order and pay.

Then, there were no napkins. Clearly, out of napkins for a long time because other customers were taking semi-used ones from other tables. I told them this behind the counter. They didn't believe me. Someone told me to look "under" (or "behind"?) the table. I looked under the table and repeated that there were no napkins. Then, they believed me. Then, someone else told me to sit down. Huh? All I want are some napkins. Our food is clearly not being touched because we would like some napkins before eating. I see some in the kitchen. I just want a few napkins. I don't understand how finding napkins really takes so long that I should sit down to wait for them.

Low on salsa everywhere too.

Meat was fairly old -- but expected that since we came between meals.

Agree with prior that it is expensive -- but they have a trendy name, so why not?

The food tasted fine to us, so that buys them star #2. My 10 month old son was happy with the avocado slices from my torta.
author: Derrick L.

description:
Well there was on day I was walking in this area and spotted this place across the street..I thought to myself(oh yum Mexican food) sounds good. At first I did a little browsing and the place looked nice on the outside and when I thought it was safe I went on in. 

I looked around and noticed how clean it was,well maybe because it was still early. However, to the left is where you see the food and then the menu of some sort is above. I was not in one of my moods to stand there and glare at everything and ponder even though there was no one behind me. I was on the go and pretty much hungry. I got a burrito and I believe it was super. Eat half at a time,you know(ha). I went with the spicy chicken,and then at first I wanted refried beans..however I went ahead and said "wait" can I change that to whole beans. I got the regular works with the extra sour cream,salsa and quacamole.The more rice,the better too. I even got a bag of chips,but I am not sure but I don't know if i was charged. It could have been $50 cents,but that is alright. 

I watched the lady make my burrito and I must skip back and say that she was quite friendly and professional when she took my order. That's good,right? 

So as I go to the resigter I pay and I thought the price was ok.However I had seen the beer on display and I was very thirsty,but I had water with me so I had to decline the bubbling eye's of the beer that wanted to be taken away from behind the counter. They offer wine too and that is nice also. 

I did find this place comfy,reasonbly priced,plenty of menu options,nice staff,clean and again the few selection of alcohol beverages would make this place a nice stop for a few drinks after work before heading out somewhere else. 

Not bad,but worth a try. 

P.S Sadly I didn't get to enjoy by burrito til way later,so it wasn't that warm anymore. The chips were ok,nothing to roll around in the bed all happy about. Regardless,the buritto tasted fine and I didn't get sick despite how late I ate it.
author: Dani D.

description:
So Iron Cactus is near my work. I only go here if I have go in this direction. Stopped here on my way back from Walgreens

1. It should not take more than FIVE minutes to make a burrito
2. Service is is horrible and slow
3. Poor quality meat (look at the carnitas in the assembly area, it's 50% fat and the carne asada look bleh
4.
author: Leo V.

description:
I eat here twice a week because it is very atkins-able.

The service staff is noticeably unfriendly on every visit.
author: John S.

description:
Came craving mexican food, and left craving mexican food.
The monster burrito was no monster. And my burrito bowl was something I could make at home. But wouldn't. Because I don't use canned beans and rice. Embarrassing. This place made me sad.
author: Jordan S.

description:
Food here is ok, the salads are the better part of the menu.

The issue here is the very slow and extremely disorganized service. Since there seems to be a lack of take-out places in 4th & Brannan area, this place gets very busy and orders seem to just disappear. Table service is even more sketchy--if you must eat here, get it to go and eat at the tables.
author: Brian H.

description:
Super wet burrito. That's right, I said it and chuckled when the guy taking my order called out for one "super wet." Yes, yes, I'm juvenile but I couldn't help it, it was funny the way it was said. 

The burrito was good and large. The wet part - spicy and flavorful. *chuckle* They have a good happy hour:

$1 tacos
$2-4 beer
$5 Margarita 

Not a bad place to kick back on a bench, down a beer, and watch the Giants game. ANd while you're at it, might as well get your mouth all hot from one that's "super wet." lol
author: Rajiv S.

description:
They've improved since opening.  I like the variety of food.

But make sure they get the order right!!!  Double check before getting your take-out.  They routinely mess up the order.
author: Oh Y.

description: decent prices, nice portions. rice and black beans tasted good but besides that... carne asada was flavorless and overall the restaurant and service was better than the food. Unfortunately I would not return here.
author: Lynn C.

description:
I've been here a couple of times.  It's really the only taco joint in the SOMA area.  So the win by location.

The people are typically very nice and conscientious.  I'm surprised by some of the other Yelp reviews about rude service.  If it is true, that's terrible.  But my experience has always been good.  I won't say they are overly effusive when it comes to customer service, but they've always be courteous.

The food is just so-so.  I ordered a carne asada taco today.  I've ordered carne asada in the past, and there just wasn't any flavor... or marinade or seasoning.  Surprising, but perhaps that's the way it's supposed to be, but the Mission taquerias tend to taste better than that.

The other stuff I ordered has just been lackluster as well.  Don't get me wrong, it's no Taco Bell, but I think I will start hopping in the car and driving to the Mission to get my Mexican fix in the future.
author: Jon S.

description:
I was very sad to see Iron Cactus with such a low rating.  I tried this place when they first opened and thought they could work out some kinks but otherwise the food was good and VERY fresh.  Since then, they seem to have their act together.

The salad is full of fresh ingredients and very generous portions.  The soup was the same, full of fresh ingredients and a large portion.  I also enjoy their baby burrito.  It's a much more manageable size than most burritos in the city.

The only thing missing for me is a full bar and margaritas.  So far only beer, wine and sangria.
author: Shanni L.

description:
It is what it is: a yuppie restaurant with a cool space next to the ballpark and CalTrains.  Your gut instinct tells you it's not good and probably overpriced too.  Still, I was hoping The Iron Cactus would be a cool addition to my hood, but it's not.  

Bland would be an understatement to describe the quesadillas and burritos, as there is absolutely no taste.  Ditto for the salsa.  Just because a "Mexican" restaurant is organic and near the ballpark doesn't mean it has to be bad, right?

Burritos and quesadillas are $7 and smaller-than-average, and a Coors Light is even $5 too.  So you're still paying ballpark prices.  

On the positive side, they have a great space, and I can see it being a fun happy hour place.  

The Iron Cactus probably targets the baseball or CalTrain crowd who just want to eat anything before they go.  Hard to see this place still being around for next year's Opening Day.
author: Manny R.

description: Top notch service, good food, and operated by the nicest man in San Francisco.
author: Mike G.

description: The location can't be beat if you're going to a ball game. And considering this proximity, the prices are very reasonable. The free chips and salsa verde were exceptional, but my meal did not live up to the verde. Not to say that you eat with your eyes, but carne asada should not be gray, and al pastor should not be hot pink.
author: Kevin M.

description:
The only reason this place still has customers is because they are so close to the ballpark.

I got the Burrito Bowl with Tofu ($7! $7 for a burrito!).  Their chips are clearly from a bag, their salsas taste stale and processed straight from a bottle.  The beans and tofu were not well cooked, and the "salad" is just iceberg lettuce.  Never have I seen such a lack of effort, especially in SF where there are amazing restaurants - especially Mexican ones.  I could've thrown together a better burrito myself, or gone to Chipotle and gotten a much healther, filling option with fresh veggies for half the price.
author: Bee M.

description:
Other than they have food, that is all you can expect from this place.
They never answer the telephone or you get a fax in your ear or they hang up on you.

I have asked for a to go Burrito 3 times with Guacamole and they keep giving me sour cream.
They do not know the difference between green and white.
Funny, since the Mexican Flag has both colors.
The help is rude, surly and obviously color blind and ignorant.
Since SOMA lacks very few restaurants, let alone good ones I would steer clear of this place unless all you want is a noisy beer, that will probably not the kind you asked for.  Try getting another one or a response!
author: Alisa Q.

description:
This place is a bummer.  
The food is barely edible.
I should have gone to McDonald's for a fast wrap.

It looks like the kind of place you could have a great burrito or some tacos and enjoy some chips, salsa and a beer or marg with friends.  The space is huge and decorated well with a great ambiance.  That is all it has going for it though.  

My chicken quesadilla order was taken and delivered with a smile.    Unfortunately it was made in a microwave.  They don't even try to hide the microwave from us, it's right there behind the counter - I didn't notice 'til I got my awful dinner.  The cheese was molten lava hot, the tortilla soggy and the meat could not have possibly been cooked the same day.  It was like chewing on chicken leather but with less flavor.

The chips and salsa were alright though.

Bottom line is a microwave has no business in a restaurant.  Ever.  EVER.  Food should have been recently prepared if not cooked just for me.  And this place blows.  

+1 star for at least looking like a good restaurant.
author: Ian M.

description:
Yelping the experience from "rock on" to "meh":

Rock On!          Decor
|                          No charge lettuce
|                          Black beans and whole wheat tortillas
|                          Friendly service
|                          Lots of menu options (bowls, soups, etc.)
|                          $6 for a baby burrito was steep, but burrito was no baby                          
|                          Mild green sauce chicken was a bit spicier than mild
Meh                   Above average wait
author: Jason B.

description:
First the good news: the people who work here are nice.  That's saying something, given that Iron Cactus is owned by the same folks who own The Creamery next door, the staff of which damn near busts the Churlish-o-meter.

In some respects, our little dinner group have only ourselves to blame for our experience.  Before we even paid for our food, before we even finished our orders, there were several warning shots fired across our collective bow.  Did we heed them?  Nay!  Damn the flavorless burrito-shaped torpedoes, full speed ahead!

Guy takes our order (friendly, as I said).  Warning shot #1: he wrote down my order and my girlfriend's order once for the kitchen, then spent a solid minute rewriting it on a second piece of paper, which he gave to us to take to the cashier.  Note there was no one else in line, so why we couldn't just order directly from the guy behind the counter is a mystery.   All ahead full!!!

Warning shot #2: by the time we got to the register, there were two women in front of us explaining the approximately 47 things that had gone wrong with their order.  Steady, into the breach!!!

Warning shot #3: as we sat down, guy at the table next to us took one bite of his food, doused himself in gasoline, lit a match, and ran screaming from the restaurant down 4th Street, ultimately flinging himself in front of a speeding Baby Bullet.

Ok, I made that one up.

Food arrives.  And sure enough, 3 of the 4 orders were wrong.  Plus, I paid $4 for an order of guacamole that never arrived.  My fish tacos were beyond bland (think tilapia sauteed with nothing but green onions) and slightly undercooked.  I'll usually eat anything you put in front of me, but this was one of the few times I literally couldn't touch my food.  It was inedible.  My girlfriend felt the same about her burrito.

Speaking of the burrito, she ordered the "small", and got a "large."  When we asked why, the waiter said, and I quote: "oh, when you order the small you get the large anyway."  Ladies and gentlemen, we are officially through the Iron Cactus looking glass.

A few minutes later, a different poor waiter came over to our table to ask how we were doing.  We were as nice as possible as we ran through our own list of the approximately 47 things wrong with our meal (seeing a pattern here?)  As we proceeded (with utmost politesse) through the litany, he literally started backing slowly away from our table, smiling embarrassedly and nodding.  By the time my friend asked for black beans rather than refried, I think the waiter had backed all the way to Harrison Street.  At the rate he was going, he's probably well past Sacramento at this point.  Hopefully finding work at a decent burrito joint.

Conclusion: the guy had been going through this all day and had reached his breaking point.  He never came back, and the meal was such a disaster that we didn't bother hunting him down.  We felt bad for him.

Mama always told me, if you don't have anything nice to say....but Mama grew up before there was Yelp, and before they opened Iron Cactus.
author: Chris L.

description:
Hi, I'm Christina and this is my first Yelp.

I'm a longtime Yelp lurker who has been siphoning all kinds of information from you wonderful people for years yet I've never felt compelled to contribute by writing a review.  I always figured someone else would shoulder the burden of finding the best happy hour specials or late-night sushi delivery.  I never thought any place I had gone to was extremely bad or good enough to merit another review.  I'm only telling you these things so you will know what a momentous occasion this first review is -- and so you will understand how strongly I feel about the experience I had at the Iron Cactus.

I initiated our small group's Friday evening dinner experience with hesitation because of the abysmal reviews thus far.  I so wanted a local Mexican joint that wasn't Chava's down the street (sorry Chava's).  I so wanted the Yelpers to be collectively wrong, their standards for a newly opened restaurant to be too high, the food to be, in truth, edible.  Lesson learned: heed the warning of 2.5 stars from 62 reviews less than a month after opening.

Talking points:

* Complete confusion in the order line.  Where does the line start?  Who takes our order?  Why is the hot food abandoned to the cold drafts from the constantly-opening door?  How can so many menu options be presented so inexplicably?  The entire ordering  & payment process begs for a do-over.

* You know that sinking feeling in the pit of your stomach when you realize something is about to go horribly wrong, just as you've predicted?  That's the feeling I had as I watched the customers in front of us mill about confusedly at the cash register, attempting to order drinks/sides, correct their orders, or explain the problems with their meals.  That sinking feeling grew more intense as I watched about 8 employees attempting to address the problems without much success.

* The food.  Sweet lord, the food.  Bland, bland, bland!  Lukewarm.  Almost entirely unseasoned and of suspect quality.  As I said to the group that night, I grew up in Vermont and am quite forgiving of bad Mexican food.  I was completely put off by my 6 dollar burrito filled with tasteless rice and sub par meat (I wouldn't even try my boyfriend's sad-looking little fish taco or my friend's "crispy" taco with a shell that looked as though it came straight from an Old El Paso box via the microwave) and the fact that I could find no redeeming qualities in any of this food says a lot.

* The mistakes.  I was floored.  My boyfriend ordered a side of guacamole that never materialized.  3 of our 4 orders had something wrong, from run of the mill errors like the wrong kind of beans to pretty unforgivable grievances like serving the wrong kind of taco altogether.  But the final nail in the Iron Cactus coffin was that our waiter, upon asking how we were doing (big mistake, buddy), listened to us explain our problems then pulled a disappearing act the likes of which I've never seen.  Not a single one of our many issues was addressed.  I felt bad for him because he's probably been dealing with this crap since the day he started -- but that doesn't mean I don't want that 5 dollars worth of guacamole you forgot.

* The menu.  Take a look at it on their website (http://ironcactussf.com/menu.php) and you'll start to understand what's going on here.  Spelling and punctuation errors (they sure do like their apostrophes) everywhere.  The chart of order options is mind boggling.  You've got to learn to crawl before you can walk.   

I beg you Iron Cactus:  take these reviews seriously and shape up.  You have the potential to bag so many loyal customers at this location, and I would have been one of them had you served me anything even close to what I can get for a lower price in the Mission, with even a modicum of precision in your service.  And if there's anyone out there who is reading this and thinking  "Meh, I shall eschew the Yelp collective's early impressions and will strike out on my own to try this place because for ME it will be different" I beg *you*:  save your money and wait it out.
author: Christina M.

description:
I live and work near The Iron Cactus and I eat there about 5 times a week. The food is great and the owners are friendly and always recognize me and make me feel welcome.

I have a myriad of intestinal disorders that make me able to only eat certain foods and the burrito bowl with guacamole does me right every time. I learned I was also lactose intolerant which a lot of people don't know they are and blame Mexican food when in fact, it's that they're lactose intolerant and should skip the sour cream! The Iron Cactus does me right and I have about one of the most sensitive guts out there.

I don't see why they don't have a 5 star rating - when the ball games are packing the place, sure, every business gets slow when you have a line out the door it seems like any place takes a long time - this place is worth the wait, every time.
author: Brent S.

description: I'm a sucker for Mexican food and this is the only one in my vicinity, so I've been a few times now. Were it not for my love of Mexican food and convenience of this place, however, I would not have gone back. The food is incredibly greasy and so doused in cheese that you can barely taste the meat. The service isn't that great either, as I always feel rushed even though the place is never busy.
author: Brett B.

description: Umm not a lot to say about Iron Cactus. The food is average. The price is a little high. They have a great location and it's not a bad place to grab a bite and a brew. Not a destination for me. Plenty of other good places to choose from with similar cuisine and better price/service
author: David R.

description:
Putting the "Meh" in "Mexican."

Dull, dull, dull, dull. Over-hyped.

Beautiful space. Flavorless food. 2 upper middle-class older (retired?) looking white people working the register area... so that immediately made me suspicious that it's just some lazy investors with money and a bunch of underpaid kitchen laborers who look the part, to cash-in on a seemingly easy cuisine, in a stunning space and in a neighborhood packed full of money to spend on lunch.

It's sad- because I don't see how these guys could fail given their proximity to local offices and the hungry wallets looking for cheap/decent eats. It is a great investment. Brilliant business move. Slap in the face to the integrity of San Francisco's commitment to creative and thoughtful (and well executed) cuisine.

No salsa bar. No selection of frescas. The one salsa they did give out with their chips (that were admittedly, delicious) was mixed like an hour beforehand... so the flavors hadn't permeated and it just tasted amateur.

Oh- and their guacamole- TOTALLY cheater/cheapie taqueria guac, with expensive avacados thinned-out by cheaper sour-cream.

Shame on the owners, for taking advantage of such a perceptibly easy cuisine and filling an incredible restaurant space with such horribly un-inspired and bland food. 

I really wanted to pan them in this review- but unfortunately for that interest, the service was incredibly quick given how slammed they were when I went in... everyone was all smiles, and the owners did seem really nice. Hoping they turn it around.
author: Nina A.

description:
