author: Jessica G.

description: Quick, good, & hot. I had the chicken burrito wet which had this really nice chargrilled taste. It was happy hour so drinks were like $3. It was empty at first but business picked up quickly. I think I liked this place cuz it wasn't Chipotle. Didn't like the flies, but I think its because they leave the door open :/
author: Shardie' T.

description: This place always always screws up my order.  The food would get a strong 4 stars if they could just get my order right.  9 times out of 10 it's wrong.  And I'm not that complicated.  If I order a Burrito bowl, I get a burrito. If I order cheese enchiladas I get chicken enchiladas.  And today I order a simple tostada; the menu says it comes with rice, no rice to be found.  I likely won't eat here again even though it's pretty good Mexican food because it drives me crazy that my order it always wrong! It is always a bit loud in there, maybe that's why?  The staff is having a hard time hearing the orders?  I don't know....
author: Sarah B.

description: Recently had our party catered by Iron Cactus because we live closeby and it was easily the best catering I've ever ordered! We originally called around to Taqueria Cancun, Pancho Villa, El Farolito (the usual places for mexican in SF) but I didn't get a good feeing about placing such a large order with them, I wasn't sure if they could handle it or even have a system in place to remember my order and I wasn't going to risk not having food at my party so I called Iron Cactus... Ivor was fantastic! He was so gracious, helpful with selections and ordering the right amount of food and amazingly accommodating and trusting. He really made it so easy for us to have an awesome taco bar spread. Everyone LOVED the food and in fact, we had sooo much leftover because of the Iron Cactus generous portions that people got to take some food home. Literally 3 dishes of everything for 40 people at a totally reasonable price because Ivor is such a strong supporter of the SOMA community!! Great, great deal. We ordered chicken steak and veggie tacos with all the sides and everything was really tasty, fresh, not overcooked (even though the quantities were large trays) Highly recommend Iron Cactus for catering or for just good mexican food. Support your local businesses if you live in the hood!
author: Cori B.

description:
I work near here so we go for lunch ever so often. The food is good - not great and not bad. I think it is on the high end of the price scale for quality, but they get away with it because of the location and the place itself is nice. I like the patio out back for lunch on nice days. Free and unlimited chips and salsa is also nice. 

Yes I will be back but having lived in the Mission for a few years I know there are WAY better Mexican places to be had. But hey, it's convenient and it's not bad.
author: Eric W.

description:
I really don't think people understand that Iron Cactus is not going to be your greasy Mission taqueria that's going to be dirt cheap with god-knows-what meat fatty goodness in your tacos and burritos. 

This is a Mexican place in SOMA next to Cal-train and Safeway for christ sake! What's wrong with you people? It's expensive because it is a mexican yuppie taqueria for all of us granola people that uses organic ingredients, no hormone meat and white chicken meat. 

I had a chicken burrito with everything in it. It was really good, had flavor and was lighter than a typical burrito--I didn't get that sicky feel (probably because it came sans the lard and grease). The service was good too.  If I wanted real good and greasy mexican food, I would take BART to Taqueria CanCun on Mission btwn 18/19th.
author: Alexandra O.

description:
Never let white people run a burritoria.  Most of the scathing remarks I wanted to make were made in other reviews, I'm going to give The Iron Cactus some free consulting:

1) Move people through line single file.  See point (2) to understand how that might be possible.
2) Organize your ingredient in the order a burrito is made.  Notice in most restaurants, they put the cheese and the burrito first, and then the fixin's in order.  That way, people can move down the line single file.
3) Eliminate the slips order tickets.  No one needs to write down an order like "burrito on whole wheat with chicken and cheese."  Write the type of burrito on the foil with an indelible pen or stick a colored toothpick into the finished burrito.  Note that (2) facilitates this.
4) Stop bringing burritos to the table.  Not only will you no longer need to employ the cute spiky-blond-haired runner to bring the burrito to my table, but you'll have customers who sit down with food.  Note that (3) is prerequisite for this.
5) Get rid of both of those dreadful salsas you have at the table.  The green one is too hot to have any taste and I've never tasted a more watery, bland roasted tomato salsa. See (11).
6) Put less rice into your burritos.  It's starchy, bland filler.  See (11) again.  Actually, go directly to (11) right now and memorize it as a mantra.
7) When you make a burrito with cheese, put it in a steamer to melt the cheese onto the burrito.  No one likes hard, cold cheese in the middle of their burrito.
8) Chips should not be extra: the cost of throwing a few chips onto someone's plate is minimal. (See (9) for clarification)
9) Source your chips from a quality chip manufacturer.  Yours tasted like a step above Doritos.
10) Take The Card (i.e., American Express).  Don't give me the crap about their fees: it's a cost of doing business.
11) Put some flavor and spice into your food.  None of the food was "bad," but newspaper has more flavor. Cilantro, chilis, peppers, pepper, salt, lime, etc. . . try 'em out.
12) "Super" option, please! 

(bonus) 13) Visit a joint like Mexico au Parc or Victor's with a notebook and copy down exactly what they do.
author: Mark J.

description: OK, so first I have to start off by saying that for the longest time, I simply always went in this place to use their restrooms with my kids before going to a game, or to see cirque du soleil or whatever.  The staff never gave me dirty looks, and was always polite in allowing me to use the restroom, which you would think they would get horribly annoyed with as I'm sure I wasn't the only one to do this.  So finally I thought it would only be fair if I actually sat and ate at this very friendly welcoming place with clean restrooms.  I really liked the burrito I ordered and my kids loved their quesadillas.  It was a great meal to eat before going to the game and eating overpriced hot dogs.  A friend recommended this place to me and I'm really glad he did.  It is walking distance to the ballpark which is really convenient in case you are on your way to a show or a game... I like to go there after a game because I would rather sit in a friendly restaurant then fight the 30min traffic jam leaving the ballpark.  Definitely worth a trip over there if you have time.
author: Aurelie C.

description:
I can't believe someone gave 5 stars for customer service! I came  here with my husband and was appalled by the service. We live in the neighborhood and like to support the local businesses. The place was for the most part empty. The people behind the counter ignored us for the first  ten minutes. Mind you there was no line and we were just waiting to order. I asked when we'd be able to order and was told "just a minute." Another 5 minutes went by (the couple in line behind us had already left) and still nothing. I told someone else working behind the counter that we had been waiting a very long time just to order and she said "sorry, just a minute." She then proceeded to other things and just ignore us.

If someone had just told us something like, "I'm sorry but we're really busy (I'm not sure how that was possible) and it will be 5 more minutes" or something like that we would have understood. To just blatantly ignore your customers is just BAD BUSINESS!! 

Needless to say, we left and went to Tres Agaves instead. We will NOT come back to Iron Cactus!
author: M. C.

description:
i gotta say - it's kinda weird getting served mexican food by a bunch of irish dudes.

is the guac made from a mix? it was uber-smooth, which is kinda impossible if you're making it fresh. unless they blended their guac, which is highly unlikely. like one person mentioned below, it ran off of everything i put it on. thumbs down.

the tofu crispy tacos were ok. i got 'em with no rice, and the ingredients themselves were pretty fresh. no complaints there.

the location is pretty cool, which I bet keeps people coming back, but would i go back? most likely not.
author: Justin H.

description:
I ordered the Carne Asada steak & shrimp plate.  

The shrimp was good but the Carne Asada was tough and flavorless.  

After taxes and tip it was $20.

Overpriced, average quality food without a full bar.
author: james b.

description: Pretty weak, I work really close to here so I'll probably be back just because of the happy hour, but the food is sub par.  Just a boring place.  If you're in Soma, you can find something way better
author: Ryan H.

description:
normally i wouldn't review a place like this but since it's so close to where i live i figure i should since i would like to see it improve.  the burritos just aren't tasty.  i think they need more flavor or salt or something...  

bland!
author: Bing S.

description: I'm still trying to find good Mexican food within walking distance to my work, but this satisfies your craving for a burrito. It's just not the best burrito ever. The salsa verde is pretty good.
author: Klevin D.

description:
Here's the deal:

Mexican food as we Americans know isn't true Mexican---it's strictly watered down for the Gringos.  True Mexican food is very complex, yet at the same time very simple and clear.

That said, it's good to see Iron Cactus in the neighborhood, because it is just one more place to eat around the SOMA/Ballpark area, and it's another takeout option, which are scarce.  The area has Fine Dining locked down, but on the rare occasions that I'm not cooking, takeout comes up short for me.

The space is warm and inviting, large, slightly cavernous, lot's of rustic wood furnishing, high, wooded beam ceilings, polished concrete floors, complete with scattered tables and a long communal table in the center.  Dimly lit, with flowers scattered here and there, which as a florist, I'm happy to see,  a large chalk board is scratched with the standard menu as well as the specials.

As this was the first day open, and I arrived 30 minutes before closing, I'd say it was relatively bug-free for the first day,  the service was fast and very friendly.  

However, the food does need a bit of work; I ordered the Crispy tacos ($3.50) which comes with your choice of meat, beans,rice, sour cream and salsa.  I chose the spicy chicken which was tender and pleasantly pulled and stringy, but was very bland for a spicy selection.  I expected the shells to be rustic, handmade corn shells, and whole thing deep-fried (similar to what they do at Dona Tomas's Tacubaya in Berkeley) but the shell I presume was pre-purchased and perhaps flash-fried, but it wasn't objectionable; thin and crisp, with a satisfying crunch, but can get soggy quickly from the whole beans (black) and the salsas and cream.  As I don't drink soda, and only drink beer unless I plan on getting laid, a nice fruity Zinfandel from Santa Cruz, from a vineyard I knew I wasn't going to remember complimented the tacos nicely.

My friend had the spicy chicken Enchilada plate (10.50) which was tasty, but again, a bit bland.  The sauce had a good flavor with an ever so slight hint of tomato, cumin and chili powder, but it wasn't very exciting to the taste buds.  The portions were adequate, which is what they should be, as I personally feel that these places serve way too much food anyway, and since I'm not looking for value for money, I'm much more interested in quality.  The burritos from what I could see resembled overstuffed dish towels, basically the usual-size burrito that you see everywhere, that most people snarf down in one sitting but would take me a week to eat.

All and all I'd say Iron Cactus satisfies the need and perhaps if they concentrate on the food, and maybe branch out and be adventurous, then they'll get better and will probably do a great business during baseball season. 

 But I don't understand why any of these Mexican places don't cook with any exciting spices; whenever I cook Mexican food, I'm using cumin seed, garlic, cayenne pepper, ancho, pasilla and poblano peppers and chiles, achiote and chile powder.  Tacqueria-style food here in the Bay Area is so bland and lifeless and tastes the same everywhere (Azteca Tacqueria is one exception).  All of the meats usually are overcooked and the chicken is boiled instead of roasted, the shrimp is rubbery , whole beans are cooked just in water and salt and the rice is always looks flavorful, but isn't.  And the Pico de Gallo which is mistaken for 'salsa' is always made with those pink insipid, cheap, fast food quality tomatoes (as was the pdg at Iron Cactus).  Although I'm adamantly against using tomatoes past their proper seasons, perhaps these places should consider using Roma tomatoes for their Pico de Gallo, if only just for the color.  A bit more expensive, but hell, this is the Bay Area!

I'd like to see some real Mexican grandmothers open up a place, and show us what real Mexican cuisine is like, or better yet, where the hell is Rick Bayless when you need him?
author: Candace W.

description: Walk in. Long line. Order a regular quesadilla with carnitas. Receive a regular burrito with carnitas. First bite... Rice. second bite... Rice. Third bite... Rice. Come on! Fourth bite... Fat! Probably the worst burrito I've had. I gave them one star cause the coca cola was cold. -__-
author: Jakob B.

description: The prices are great and so is the food. Iron Cactus is tops.
author: Alyse M.

description:
really, a 3.5 star review, but i'll bump it up to counter the haters. 
first day, not bad. the carnitas tacos i had were heaping and pretty tasty. the other dishes they had out for display, such as the camarones, looked pretty good as well. a couple of things really kept it from being a much stronger spot:

- no salsa bar. i know you are trying to be fancy, but some of us need our pico de gallo, man. 

- tacos had only one torilla, and it was steamed, making it gummy and sticky (i even had trouble getting it off the waxed paper). either grill that thing, or up it to two torillas.

- an option for "super" on the tacos would have been awesome, as i really could have gone for some guac. 

anyway, like i said, first day. this place has a lot of potential,and hopefully they can rise to it.
author: Tom H.

description: AVOID!! The food is tasteless and the staff are terrible. Don't be shocked when the staff gets your order wrong. You've been warned.
author: Ricky J.

description: Fast, cheap, and delicious when you take the sparse selection of other restaurants in walking distance! Best... as in ONLY... mexican restaurant on the block!
author: Brian W.

description:
It's a darn shame that these folks have such a wonderful location and decor, yet have some how managed to completely butcher Mexican cuisine. 

In San Francisco, where one can get the best tacos, burritos and salsas for dirt cheap, it's difficult to try and compete. Unless you're positive you have a unique flair or at least have mastered the art of cooking delicious Mexican, than why bother?

I wouldn't recommend eating here. I was unsatisfied with every dish I tried: flavorless fish tacos, stale, over cooked chicken, tasteless cheese quesadilla, and the worst guacamole ever to grace my tongue. (The Costco brand does it better.)

My recommendation to the owners - don't waste your space - find a new chef!

PS- On a side note I just found out my wallet was stolen from the register where I left it behind. Usually it's put in a lost in found especially when it's sitting at the register, but come to find out that they're completely not responsive to my request to find it. Coincidentally all charges were made at nearby locations just after there location closes. VERY DISAPPOINTING ALL AROUND.
author: Raquel T.

description: I've only tried the tacos they offer for happy hour. It's all bad my friend. I lived in San Antonio for 10 years, I know what a good taco tastes like. I did not find any here.
author: L W.

description: Didn't actually eat as i was there to catch the Giants Braves game but it smelt good and everyone's dishes looked pretty darn good. Great place to hang out at and you can always bring a coffee in from the Creamery next door
author: Pilar M.

description:
HAPPY HOUR!

$2 tacos the size of your face.

Tough economic times.  What's not to love.
author: Jeff P.

description: If you like generic mexican food and need help with pictures then this is place for you.
author: Alan M.

description:
This place is certainly not suffering from a "they're new, they have a lot of kinks to figure out" problem.  They're suffering from a "the food is really pretty terrible, and horrendously overpriced" problem.  
Figured the gf and I would give the new workplace neighbor a try for lunch.  The ordering process was a bit chaotic and left a lot of room for errors...errors including who I assume is the co-owner not ringing me up for my carnitas taco.  
The ambiance is actually pretty cool and fits with the whole warehouse SoMa vibe, but clearly the proprietors spent much more time on the decor than the menu.
Back to the food.  My tortilla soup came out luke warm and PILED with chicken and accompanied by three plastic cups of toppings (wtf?):   cojita, tomatoes and corn.  Normally I wouldn't complain about the overabundance of meat, but the soup was a failure.  The broth was one-note, not at all spicy, and the whole thing entirely devoid of actual tortilla strips.  I'd give it a 2/10 on a good day.
My mistakenly gratis taco was just as unimpressive, though the pork itself wasn't terrible.  The worst part about this dish by far was the fact that the moist corn tortilla almost entirely stuck to the paper beneath it.  See ya later, hand to mouth taco eating.  
I'll take my business back to Au Parc, or better yet, wait until after work to hit up La Taq or Papalote to get my fix.
author: Dean F.

description: I came here on opening day 2011 as part of a large party. The Beer was good and cold although the first pitcher was $20 and the second was $25, still good though. Ordered a hamburger along with 4 others, all 4 were brought with varying degrees of condiments though ordered by 1 person at one time. The burgers were seared only-raw,raw,raw inside. the one bite I took was very flavorful though, and juicy-----blood red. I had read the reviews before going and was wondering if it could be that bad. IT IS THAT BAD. want a burger go around the corner to Burger Joint. Want Mexican food, go anywhere else but here. Want a Beer, come here and buy it by the glass. The help was friendly that day anyway. AVOID AT ANY COST IF HUNGRY.
author: Mark S.

description:
The best "super burrito" on the planet can be found at the Iron Cactus. As well as the best "al pastor". Their margaritas and drinks are outstanding. I am a connoisseur of healthy Mexican food, and the Iron Cactus is superb.

But there is more to this restaurant than the food. The owners are some of the kindest people I've meet. I left my wallet there by accident once, and they called me immediately to return it the next day. That says it all.

Easily the best Mexican food in Soma.
author: Shahram S.

description: I had to convince myself to give a two star (upgrade) rating.   Because in the end the food was alright.   The service however, was underwhelming.  And I wasn't expecting a lot because it's basically a buffet line.  I'm not gonna go into it except to say, it just didn't go well with the cashier when I was trying to place an order.  The wait was a little lengthy and by the time the food arrived...  The picnic table seating which I originally thought was charming and a set up from the typical Taqueria seating...was not so comfortable and charming anymore.   The portion of guacamole was nearly micorscopic.    ...Bad news for a guac-addict.   But like I said the food tasted decent.   Guess I gotta stick to Colibre or Maya for more upscale Mexican.
author: Michael W.

description:
I went here for lunch today and am am now baffled that I came back to my computer and Yelp and saw an avg of 2.5 stars?? Definitely not. 4 stars. solid.

For what it is I thought it was great!  mexican food, order at the counter, get a number, they bring it to your table. I thought they also had a nice lot of seating, with some outside too. It's not in the mission so maybe it's a few dollars more than some other burrito spots, but whatever, this was more convenient.

I had the baby burrito and my boyfriend had the regular burrito. The baby one was noticably smaller, but was it enough food? Of course! I got the spicy chicken with black beans, and there was also rice and salsa inside. The lady taking my order asked if I wanted it spicy so of course I said yes. Perk: free basket of chips and two kinds of salsa!! I definitely liked the spicy red one better than the green one. 

By the time I finished my burrito and chips/salsa my mouth was feeling the heat ...just how I like it. 

I probably wouldn't recommend going out of your way to come here, but if you are going to be in the area and are looking for an under $10 meal, well then I would definitely recommend it. By baby burrito with chips and salsa was $5.95 (ok $6-something including tax)
author: Caitlin B.

description: Unbelievable.....BAD, SLOW, EXPENSIVE.  Ordered a torta with the al pastor meat (bbq pork) to go which was over $9. I watched and waited 20 minutes while they made burritos for people who were behind me in line.  Finally, I sat down to eat the torta at my office and to my surprise, there was barely any meat; should have been piled on like a burrito.  The meat was spread thin like peanut butter.  Additionally, no napkins and salsa were provided, they didn't even ask.   Torta was bland.  This place is on the SHIT LIST for good.
author: Nelson F.

description: when you get five tacos for a few people and they ask to upsell you to super tacos, say NO.  otherwise you've just bought five tacos for 30 bucks.  what. the. f.
author: brian w.

description: The  Iron Cactus has a great location and look unfortunately the food is really lacking. If you don't like cold spots in your burrito this is the place for you, because my whole burrito was piping cold. Both friends also had plates of lukewarm food that took too long on serving time and short on flavor. The quesadillas were soggy and bland despite the cashier asking us if we wanted "crispy tortillas" and "spicy salsa".  One thing the place has going for it in the food department is that the carne asada on my burrito was tender. But unfortunately it was not warm. Did we hit an off night? Maybe. Am I willing to go back to Mission Bay to give it a second shot. No.
author: Joshua W.

description:
This restaurant is right around the corner from where I work.  They have a patio in the back which is a nice place to eat on sunny days.  They make a pretty good chicken salad, but everything else is kind of so-so.  The service is horrible.  Someone who can barely speak English takes your order, and I always have to repeat it.  Then they ask you questions like "wat kine bane?".  "What?" "Block bane, peento bane..."  "Oh, black beans, yes, that will work."  You almost feel like the Soup Nazi's shop as they hand you a number and shuffle you down to the next person who you hand your order to.  "No, you keep number", she says. (you are supposed to know this)  You give her the cash, she never offers you a drink (not once in my 10+ visits there), and then she prints out the receipt AND KEEPS IT.  Yes, they never give you a receipt (this comes into play later).  So, do they call my number, bring it to me...?  Unless you a regular, you won't know unless you ask.  

On Monday, March 25th around noon, I went there with my friend for lunch.  I ordered the chicken salad and he ordered some tamales.  His order came to $20 (foreshadowing here).  We went out to the patio.  They first brought out his food, then, a few minutes later, we hear a sneeze, followed by a second sneeze as the "food runner" dude (or whatever he is called) "tried" to cover his sneeze with his arm as my food was held below his sneeze.  He handed me the food and pulled a handkerchief out of his pocket and started to wipe his nose.  The food runner dude was sick!!  My friend, who saw the whole thing, said "I wouldn't eat that. He sneezed on it, I saw him".  So, I took it back.  When I took it back and explained what had happened, the food runner dude denied it, saying he covered his mouth (he was wiping his nose again and was clearly sick).  You are missing the point, dude, YOU ARE SICK!  WTF ARE YOU SERVING FOOD FOR?  YOU ARE BLOWING YOUR NOSE AND HANDLING MY FOOD!  Well, he gave the food to the ladies behind the counter who looked confused.  I wouldn't leave.  I wanted to see them remake my salad and I would take it back to my table.  Well, it sat there for at least 5 minutes.  Then, they walked it to a counter between the front and back kitchen.  WTF?  The food is supposed to be prepared in front!  After about 10 minutes, they bring the food back.  Before I could get to it, the sick dude got his grubby hands on it and handed it to me.  I told this that this is the same salad as before except you could see the meat was hot.  I asked them what they did, and they said, no, the food was made in the back.  I told them the salads were always made up front (this is like a Subway shop with all the ingredients in bins behind glass in front) as they make it in front of you.  I was very hungry and walked back to my table.  I looked at the food and took a little bite of the avocado, then decided it wasn't worth the risk.  I am almost positive it was the same salad with newly cooked meat on top.  I decided to go grab a Subway sandwich instead.

Three days later, I end up with the flu.  Coincidence?  I haven't been sick all season.

Side note about my friend and his tamales. They overcharged him.  Since they don't give you a receipt, he couldn't check.  So, he went back and complained, they found his receipt, and his $20 meal should have been $12.

So, two strikes against them in one day.  If you decide to eat there, you have been warned.  There are several better choices of Mexican food in the area.  They have lost my business, and as I spread the word throughout my office, I think many coworkers will think twice.
author: Mike J.

description:
This place is very disorganized and slow.

It took them forever to take our order and then write it out and give us the receipt, which the cashier couldn't even read.

I got a burrito bowl which was essentially a bowl of iceberg lettuce topped with a scant amount of beans, rice, and meat. Quite a rip for $10.

I'm giving 2 instead of 1 star because the chicken actually didn't taste that bad, but it was dry and stringy.
author: Saikat P.

description:
This place has potential, but right now it's sittin' at 2.5 stars for me. With a few minor changes they'd easily be 3 stars in my book, maybe even up to 4 stars, but that would take more.... I'll get to that. 

I've been here twice so far- first time had the taco salad with tofu, second time had a veggie burrito with tofu. I'm fairly certain the burrito had more lettuce in it than my salad did. I couldn't really taste the gauc in my burrito, or the sour cream, and come on now, the cheese should be included (not cost extra!). The rice was, to be honest, pretty crap- mushy, and spicy- but not in a flavorful way. The rice needs to be not total mush and it'd be nice to have a plain rice option, or at least a less seasoned one. Also, there were soggy peas and carrots in my burrito- these things have no place being in a burrito. This is not Forrest Gump goes to the tacqueria, people- leave the mushy canned veggies out!

As for the tofu, I think they might be using silken tofu, or at least it tastes that way- the tofu needs to be grilled and firmer. I know, I know, it's TOFU, it's not supposed to taste great... but the thing is, when it's done well, it does. This tofu is mushy and tasteless. I think this would be a fairly easy fix- buy extra firm tofu, prep it correctly, grill it, don't leave it sitting in a vat of water/sauce with soggy canned vegetables.

The salad, too, would be an easy fix- add more lettuce, maybe mixed greens.... as it was, I felt like I was eating a bowl full of toppings. Blech. 

Ok, now the pros, and the potential-
I LOVE the atmosphere here. Actually, so much so that it sets my expectations really high- the great decor with dark wood and beautiful lanterns make me feel like I'm in a nice Mexican restaraunt, not a grab n' go burrito place.....and so it follows that I expect certain things. Namely, margaritas. When this place opened, I read the menu 4 times just to make sure I wasn't missing something. "How can a Mexican place not have Margaritas???"  It looked like the kind of place that would have great ritas. Yes, I know, Tres Agaves is right down the street, and yes, I understand this is a taqueria (even though it looks like a restaraunt), and that liquor licenses are expensive, but I still want a darn 'rita. Pitchers of them would add so much to this place. A 'rita  alone would add a star or two here. I hear they have sangria, which helps, but it's still not a margarita. Also, good sangria has booze in addition to wine in it, so I'm skeptical....unless they just get a liquor license. 

More on pros: beer on draft, good beer selection, and very generous wine pours. The chips are pretty good. Outdoor patio and convenient location. Friendly staff. 

Like I said, potential. But right now my favorite part is the decor, not the food.
author: Kristen L.

description: Not the best burrito I have ever had.  Not the worst burrito I have ever had.  Not the cheapest burrito I have ever had.  Not the most expensive burrito I have ever had.  This place is straight up average.
author: Caleb R.

description: I'm a big fan of this place. Sure it isn't the most authentic mexican food you can get in San Francisco. But, it is fresh, healthy and flavorful. The portions are big and the prices are very reasonable. I was so happy when this place moved in because SOMA really needs more locally owned mom and pop type restaurants, which this place is. The staff and owners are always nice and its just an overall nice place to eat. Lots of room, nice decor and the back patio is great on sunny days. My favorite dishes are the mexican grilled chicken salad, tortilla soup and the grilled chicken burrito.
author: Heron C.

description: I really think these reviews are off base.  Yes maybe the burrito might be better in the mission at a few places but I only get Tacos here primarily and they are delicious.  The Carnitas and Chicken are especially good and the Carne isnt bad also.  But on Tuesday the mini tacos are the best.  1 dollar tacos and 2 dollar coronas are great.  The green sauce they have table side is up there with Cumbre on 16th and Valencia and Cancuns hots green salsa.  The people who work here push this place over to a 5 star review from 4.  Such friendly and nice people.  I always enjoy going here not only for the food and atmosphere but for the great people who work at this restaurant make it a truly great experience.  I will be there tomorrow again for delicious tacos and 2 dollar coronas to support the best Mexican restaurant in SOMA.
author: Harry E.

description:
this place goes down to 2 stars,
they cut the hours of the happy hour, and it only covers tacos + beer
no more nachos BOOO!

----------------------------------------------
I'm not rating this based on taqueria quality in relation to other taq's in SF, but solely based on the amazing happy hour deals which I had previously ignored until today.

M-F 3-6pm half price apps or $2 tacos, which makes a regular order of nachos just over 2 bucks (this is a standard size square box filled up too).

Pros:
-veg option friendly (tofu)
-refried black beans (only seen at papalote and the revamp pancho villa)
-decent green salsa, nothing amazing
-house made tortilla chips make any nachos better
-Convenient location right across from the 4th Caltrain, which makes it easy if I need to wait a while for the next train.

Negs:
regular price I probably wouldn't repeat - although I may choose this over Victor's in the area, but not mexico au parc in south park - burritowise
author: Jefferson C.

description: its a tad bit pricy, but everythign in that area is. Its definitely a lot cleaner than your average mexican joint, and healthier too.
author: boston j.

description: I'll give the food two stars and the service ZERO!! Guy taking orders basically rolled his eyes at me when I started giving him my order. Could they be any more rude?!!! Lady collecting money tried charging me $25 for a simple burrito and almost started arguing with me about it. Burrito was ok but I have definitely had better. People need to start respecting their customers if they want them to come back. Horrible service.
author: Lucy G.

description: super meh. $10 for a Tostada Salad? ok... fine. but really? it was the smallest tostada salad I've ever had. And the most expensive. save your money. also i stood in the front of the line for 5 minutes with 4 staff members doing their best to ignore me.
author: Joe G.

description:
Who: My brother and I.
What: My brother is obsessed with Mexican food.
When: For a late lunch, 2 PM.
Why: I grabbed the fish tacos, and guacamole, my brother grabbed the burrito. Great location, seeing that I live only 2 blocks away and there are no other taquerias nearby. The only negative thing I saw at this new place was there were no substitutes for ingredients that they made to order. For example, on my fish tacos, instead of sour cream I wanted guacamole and was told very strictly, that there were NO substitutes. Interesting at a made to order place. But the fish tacos were excellent as well as guacamole. And my brother who should be the King of Burritos was impressed by his steak burrito. A huge plus that this place is attached to my favorite coffee place- The Creamery.
author: R P.

description: so me and my coworker tried this place out during our lunch break. we go in and was a little confused as to where to order but a gentleman at the counter called us over. the menu is pretty basic so i ordered a quesadilla. the cashier was a very friendly lady. we went to sit down and noticed other people around us had chips and we didn't have any...eventually they were delivered but right before our meal came. i was a little concerned over the runner as he is the same person bussing and cleaning tables. i worked in the food and beverage industry and i know better than to have my busser run food out without cleaning his hands. but we got our food and it looked amazing. i thought it was pretty good for the price i pay. i enjoyed the spanish rice very much. and the decor and furniture was definitely different. i liked the feel of the place, very spacious and welcoming.
author: Zara-Maria S.

description:
The restaurant business is hard. So much competition, overhead etc. So when a new place opens and they don't take care of the things they CAN control it makes me wonder how much they actually want to succeed.  Its easy to be friendly. It doesn't cost anything and it makes newcomers feel like they matter. Its easy to train your employees to know how the food is being prepared. Its easy to make fresh batches of sangria instead of leaving an empty pitcher of old fruit in plain sight shrugging  your shoulders and saying, "we're out of sangria"....MAKE SOME MORE DUDE!!!!.

Rude and unconcerned service. Chips so thin that the nachos were a soggy pile of corn mush just moments after arrival.  Get it together.  I won't go back. Victors is better. Mexico AuParc even more so. Adios.
author: Mark B.

description: The food is pretty bland. My fish tacos tasted fresh but had no flavor. Same goes for rice and beans. Horchata was just ok.. I might go back to try the salad.
author: anna p.

description: There are better Mexican places in the city, but there are worse too. In fact Victors down the road is worse. At least this place has a patio and beer on tap. OK, but nothing special.
author: Stephen C.

description:
This place is fantastic! I moved right around the corner from the Iron Cactus a couple of months ago and and have been going here twice a week ever since. The atmosphere is great, especially during sports games, I love the look of the place, staff is always really friendly and recognizes me every time I come in and, oh ye the whole reason I come here, ... my Super Burrito! 

The place seems to be doing very well and is always packed before and after the Giants games. Another good thing is that they have whole wheat tortillas here!!! something which I can never find at Chipotle. 

My girlfriend loves the chicken tacos they have here too and on Tuesday they are only 1$ each. Finally, the fact that I can get my Cappuccino right next door makes me a happy customer.

Basically I am very grateful to have the Iron Cactus in my neighborhood and love getting my lunch and dinner here on a weekly basis. I would like to see more fun places like this in SF!
author: Sebastiaan v.

description:
Don't even know what to say about this place. As people below state, trust your gut instinct. I'm mexican and know what REAL mexican food is, bottom line it doesn't reallllly exist in SF (minus late night tacos de adobada o carnitas). In noo way did I walk expecting this to even compete with Chavos or other "staples" of the SOMA & ballpark corridor. BUT this won't even compete with Chevys, yes ...that bad. Being a so cal kid, sometimes I admit I crave a cheesy syrup based margarita and nasty chips n salsa = el torito, but THIS place makes el torito seem like an awesome eatery in Jalisco. ajjjuaaa
-Service was nice...
-space is great
-location is cool
The only reason I walked in there was the fact I was craving chips n salsa... ended up ordering flautas because the guy across the street @ ups said "dont get the fish tacos, it taste like fish flavored tofu" bad sign but still as a believer in trying the new hood places, even at a cool $12 for a plate of flautas. 
Bottom line it was horrible... even the salsa sucked and as I was paying I said "ok I'll pay for chips if they aren't included" cashier said "oh noo they will be in ur bag". Got back to my office.. didn't even care about the flautas, but searched and searched and no chips. 

I wanted to get chipfaced and didn't get the chance to. 

Sooo ni modo iron cactus... suerte para la proxima. Can we do minus -1 star?
author: Gen O.

description: I had lunch at the Iron Cactus to give it a second chance and I'm glad I did.  I had two fish tacos and it was very tasty.  The service is much better...the employees are polite, and there seems to be a working process now.  Bravo on the improvements!
author: Sarah B.

description: I brought my 2 friends from work to The IC last week, and we had the garlic prawns plate and the Chiplote Prawns which were great.....
author: Victor T.

description: Food ok.  Service horrible and incredibly slow.  I waited 25 minutes of my 30 minute lunch break for a fish taco.
author: Karen Z.

description: My review will be biased since there are no other mexican restaurants (other than Tres agaves) in the 5 block radius of my SOMA apartment.  This place is good for a quick burrito and it's *definitely* improved since opening.  We don't have a taco truck :( and this ain't the mission, so when I'm craving mexican this does the job.  And it's relatively cheap and fast.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
expensive... slow... disorganized... salty rice... 

sangria is okay... 

I give this review about as much attention as the cactus gives towards it's customer service and food quality.
author: Stacey W.

description: Great place to watch a game, drink a beer and have some delicious mexican food.  Service was great too.
author: Hawk M.

description: Yet another taco joint within a 3 block radius from my office in SOMA.  Same folks responsible for the Creamery next door.  Only twist - locally sourced and sustainable Mexican food.  Watch out kiddies, that's code for "I gonna charge you more for the same old shit".  Nice addition to the work neighborhood, but to be honest the food is better from the taco truck one block away from my office.
author: Vince B.

description: This place is terrible. I work across the street and it would be so nice to have an actually good Mexican place right here - but Iron Cactus has awful service, an apathetic wait staff, and unimpressive eats. Somehow it's always crowded between Giants games and weekday lunchtimes - but I'd recommend Victor's around the corner for much better food and friendliness.
author: Lina L.

description: Watched the Euro on Saturday at this great South Beach taqueria.  The food is excellent, very authentic.  I had the sopes plate, which was delicious.  And a great place to watch a sporting event, especially soccer!
author: Chad H.

description: The seafood entrees here are wonderful .... fish tacos, shrimps ... very good!  I recommend the quesadillas second behind seafood entrees.  4th Street is becoming a nice food corridor.  There's a very nice decor about the place .... whereas most mexican restaurants in the area are really intended for grab and go, the seating and set up here is actually inviting to sit around, have some beer, and enjoy the company of your friends while munching on the tasty mexican dishes.
author: Jamie W.

description:
Having seen the Cactus being built as it's just down the street from me I was excited to check it out last Friday after a long day at work.
First off - this isn't really a restaurant, it's more of a fast food joint. You order your grub at the counter, pay for it and take a number. Nothing wrong with that (almost all the best Mexican food I've had was from street vendors), just don't come here expecting white table cloths and a mariachi band.
Unfortunately the level of service is belied even by the humble interior (I guess they're going for the faux vintage look that's inexplicably still popular in SOMA). It took 5 minutes to explain my complicated order of 2 soft tacos, 2 crispy tacos and a 'dilla to the cashier. After that she inexplicably decided to tack on a burrito to my order. The manager was pleasant, however, and quickly refunded me the burrito bucks.
The food took significantly longer than I expected to arrive, and when it did it was savory but not spectacular. None of the dishes were memorable and the ingredients, while allegedly fresh, were rather bland and had to rely on the salsa for flavor.
If the Iron Cactus gets competent staff and jazzes up their dishes (or at least obtains a full liquor license so they can serve margaritas) then they have all the makings of a success. Until then I'll keep getting my neighborhood Mexican fix at Tres Agaves.
author: Max G.

description: I'm happy to finally have a decent taqueria walking distance from work and this place has a lot of potential but is falling short.  The 3 stars are for organic, sustainable ingredients, the happy hour deals and the mini burrito.  The food is overpriced and the service is extremely slow for an establishment that caters to lunch for 9-5ers.
author: Laura S.

description: Great place to have a beer.  Wasn't impressed with the food, but the local service was good.
author: Chris A.

description:
The food is mediocre and the service is average. The takeout procedure is poor. I've called several times and gotten a busy signal and have had to wait fir an order that was places on the phone. I suggest that the owners shape up the management to be less type b. The best parts about this place is the design and the location.

Since this is a new place the owners can still turn the ship around.
author: Frequent D.

description: Good place for a diet. Burritos seem muy poquito - I guess their focus is on healthy portion sizes.
author: Johnson H.

description: Edible, but bland and overpriced. The spicy salsa was totally flavorless. And $7 for a veg burrito that doesn't even have avocado? Come on.
author: peter j.

description: This restaurant has wonderful tasting food, and great ambiance. I just could not give it the fifth star. We arrived 10 minutes after they were to be opened. The door was still locked. Not all meats were ready so could not get my favorite - carnitas. Then after ordering went to register and was informed that they could only take cash as the machine for cards was not warmed up. Humm? I will return and hope all is in order the next time around. I love the taste of the salsas and the friendliness of the people.
author: S F.

description: OK, I don't think there's any reason a review and rating for a restaurant can't be based on trying just one or two items.  With that said...I find it hard to believe that they can't get even a simple bean and rice burrito to taste decent.  I have on two occasions asked them to make this spicy and both times now it's about as bland and unspicy as I think is possible to make it.  And the salsa used might as well be genetically modified cardboard.  Blah!  Also tried some fish tacos once and they were equally null and void of flavor.  I think I'll pass on this place in the future.
author: j d.

description: Bangin' happy hour (for SOMA). Right now that's all I can afford. Food is not totally awesome (even for SOMA). But ~*~*~ patio ~*~*~ !
author: Miranda E.

description: For a place that has only been open 2 weeks, I was impressed. We went for happy hour and got 4 tacos and 2 pints for about $15.00. Rice and beans was also included. The atmosphere was very nice, especially for a place where you order at the counter. The service was friendly, and the food was fresh. They also give you a healthy serving of sour cream, which is something I typically see Mexican restaurants skimp on. Will definitely return to this spot, especially for happy hour or a quick lunch.
author: Michael C.

description: Went back again today, this place seriously rocks.  The chicken burrito "wet" with spicy ranchero sauce was fantastic, service was friendly and fast, the portions were huge, and the price point was right on target.  This is the best mexican restaurant in the area, hands down.
author: Chase N.

description: Meh. . . not that great. El Tonayese still has my vote.
author: Cat B.

description: I really wish The Iron Cactus had good food because SOMA is lacking a less formal Mexican restaurant open on the weekends. Their coffee shop is great, Mexican food not so much.
author: David R.

description: 5 stars for the only good tofu burrito in the city.  Also, the architecture somehow makes the food taste better.
author: Krishan G.

description: Went here for a quick dinner because it was super close to my apartment.  The chicken on my salad was amazing -- I was surprised at just how good it was.  Boyfriend had a burrito and thought it was just fine.  If you're in the mood for quick Mexican and you're in the area, check it out.  Good food but probably not good enough to trek all over SF for.
author: Christina S.

description:
Ah Yelp, you're too funny. They just opened so they got a bunch of 1-star reviews whilst still optimising. Enough already. 

The food here is very reasonably priced and very fair. If you want better spend the money at Tres Agaves or go to the Mission. However, if you're in SOMA, this is a fabulous place for a quick mex meal. The beer selection is great and growing. The decor is attractive. It brings new light to a once dingy part of the neighbourhood. And they have an outdoor garden where they are extremely welcoming to dogs with their owners (on leash please!). 

A welcome addition to the neighbourhood. Enough with the 1 star reviews.
author: Nick W.

description:
We went there on Tuesday night aroudn 8PM.
It was not too busy so we walked right up to the counter.
We both love burritos so I ordered the beef and my partner ordered the chicken.   
Like many of the reviews we were amazed that we had to pay extra for CHEESE???   (I am from Wisconsin where normally cheese is included on everything for free :-)

I should have looked at my receipt because I saw someone mention that they charge 50cents for chips?   I just assumed they came with it and they were on my plate.  I will have to check on that.  Its not very clear.

The other odd thing was there was a guy there that I think was the owner or manager.  He walked around in and out of the kitchen.  He looked exhausted and very unhappy.   I am sure starting a restaurant is a nightmare but if it was me I would have put on a happy face and said hello to people and welcomed them and asked them how things were.   He basically ignored the existence of all the customers never once talking to anyone but the staff???


The space is great.  The people were friendly to us but the food was my big concern reading the reviews.  Luckily both of us really liked our burritos and they were pretty good size.  I have to say the steak had some really good seasoning.   What I didnt like was the little salsa containers on the tables.  I just do not think that is sanitary having little social salsa pots all over the place.   This is a city full of all kinds of people and I dont know what the last 10 people did with that container and spoon.  ugh.... I wish I could have gotten my salsa from a salsa bar or on the side.

So to sum it up:

Pros:
Food was good
Burrito was good size
Atmosphere is cool but mellow


Cons:
Cheese is extra?  Wrong....
Public salsa jars - yuck
Needs a personality.  Staff was nice but distant - manager had head in sand.

Recommendations to owners:
Offer a "super" or "wet" burrito including all the options - guac, sour cream, cheese, salsa etc. s
Salsa bar... or salsa on the side
Ask your patrons what they think - smile and welcome them...

Chow!
author: Kev S.

description: The first time I came here, it was great no doubt about it.  I ordered their super burrito and it was HUGE and delicious.  I couldn't wait to go back.  NOW second time around - I ordered the super burrito again, paid $9.58 for the damn thing, got it, looked in the bag and sincerely thought they got my order wrong.  This burrito (if that's what you want to call it) was the size of a banana, no joke.  I went back up to the counter to explain that there must have been a mistake.  The guy at the register looks at me like I'm crazy and says "Nope, it's a super".  OK I'm not an idiot, last time I was here the "super" was a lot larger than a banana, and I was actually satisfied that my ten bucks was well spent.  But sure enough this asshole rudely told me that I was wrong and that my banana size burrito was indeed a super.  I will NEVER ever go back to this place.  Rude customer service, and they have no problem ripping you off.  I will be telling everyone I know not to come here.
author: Kerry Z.

description: We have been going here since it opened about a month ago, and it's gotten consistently better. We are happy to have new restaurants open up in this neighborhood, especially ones that aren't upscale and expensive. The atmosphere is nice, the food good, and the service friendly. It's become one of our favorite places to eat out. And bonus points for being right by the train station, making it a quick grab to take home after the commute from the south bay.
author: Pani P.

description: This is one of the worst mexican food joints i've been to.  The interior is nice and big, but the food is horrendous.  The meat is very dry and it's basically a wannabe chipotle.  There is no flavor whatsoever.  In fact, I'd say that the meat tastes so dry it's like an iron cactus.  I have been here more than once too, i dont' know what possessed me to come back the second time.  If it was possible, i'd kick myself in the head for doing such a thing.  It is overpriced as well.  I'd NEVER go here again.
author: pert u.

description:
I'm beginning to feel that Yelp only publishes -ve reports until it gets its payola????  Either that, or all the folks who had bad experiences eat at places in Paris, France.  Not!!!  Certainly from the crappy writing, goes along with their crappy attitudes.  Get a life guys!  Want top star qualities, go pay for it or shut up!  I did find it pretty funny that 2 cute Irish guys run a Mexican restaurant.  Love the workers, down to earth and happy not like some of their customers!  Did agree with the experience of a very unpleasant white woman behind the counter.  I find the food warm and fuzzy just like the ambiance & the people who work hard at cooking and serving it.  Just glad to have one more choice in Mission Bay other than Panera & Amici's, not that I dislike either of them.  But for a change...  Do wish they were open later to accommodate some of us who work late & hate to cook.
eb
author: Evelyn B.

description: Not the best, but not bad.  Very very convienient, and the guacamole appetizer is huge!
author: n k.

description:
Come on Yelp-sters, give this kid a chance.  I happen to work around the corner from this place, and I've been there a half-dozen times since it opened.  
Yes, the first week the food was rough around the edges.  
But it's coming together.  The breakfast burrito on Sunday was fantastic.

And the space is nothing less than great -- vaulted ceilings with exposed original wood, and a skylight.  It's becoming a solid place to throw back lunch, in a neighborhood desperate for something (anything) decent.
author: Mike D.

description: I loved the idea of another mexican restaurant in the area but the flavor was not good not mexican but americanized. The food gave me a stomach ache I will never return I like true Mexican Chava's a couple blocks up is a small unattractive hole in the wall with way better mexican food.
author: monica f.

description: rubbery shrimp, dried out and tasteless al pastor, both surrounded by guac, rice, and bland refrieds on tortillas. so completely disappointing.
author: Will R.

description: I love this place. The happy hour rocks! It's so close to my office. So happy we have this next to Caltrain too. I just had an awesome fish taco and huge nachos for $6!!!
author: Amanda H.

description:
I live across the street from TIC.  It opened right along with our moving in.  They also own the Creamery coffee shop attached - i thought this was a great model.  I wanted to take a moment to give a huge high five review for this restaurant.  Amidst the vast array of greasy spoon styled Mexican food spots (which don't get me wrong, I love as well), The Iron Cactus stands out as a healthy, thoughtful and noteworthily flavored option.  The basic foods chosen are all organic.  All chicken meat is white and of the highest grade.  The chicken tortilla soup is to die for as is the ceviche.  The moles used for burritos give them a great spin from the norm.  I highly recommend a stop in if you haven't tried.

Beyond that, the service is exceptional - everyone is so polite, service oriented, and just all around nice.  I walked by during an electrical outage that had the entire 2 block radius out of service and they kept doors open with candles and everyone sitting eating together.  

Please take a moment to support this new locally owned restaurant.  Hopefully you'll add as a favorite.
author: P H.

description:
The way they make you order is so inefficient. Instead of making the burrito while you pick your ingredients, they write everything down first and make you wait a really long time while they make it. And even though they wrote my order down they STILL got it wrong. They also make you pay extra for everything- cheese, sour cream, guacamole. 

When I asked them to make a chicken fajita burrito with grilled peppers and onions, they told me "we're not allowed to give you that" even though I've gotten it two times before. 
I like the refried black beans that you can't find at every Mexican place, but other than that not that great... 
It has the potential to be a lot better.
author: Seeta S.

description: My first Yelp! review in honor of the terrible service I experienced today. I live across the street and so keep giving this place another chance, but NEVER again. Usually it's just bad food and mediocre slow service. Today, I left without any food because the guy first messed up my order, then threw away the last of a key ingredient so the order couldn't be fixed, and then proceeded to give me major attitude. Don't say you can make me a simple salad if you can't! I'm done with this place for good. Even if I lived inside The Iron Cactus I wouldn't eat there. For nice people and good Mexican, go around the corner to Victor's.
author: N G.

description: Popular Spanish restaurant almost right across the street from the Caltrain station. I had a steak burrito, which unfortunately was worse than my usual steak burritos from Chipotle. The food itself wasn't bad at all, but the steak tasted almost chewier than usual and didn't have quite as much flavor. When I got it, I was surprised to feel that one side was unusually cold, while the other side was piping hot. Although I was concerned that I would have to return it to the kitchen, I unwrapped it only to find all the hot items on one side, while the cold corn and vegetables were in another section. The atmosphere of the restaurant was quite lively, but the music from the radio often drowned out our conversation at the table. I appreciated the TV in the corner though, which was set on a news channel reporting news. It reminded me a little bit of being back at Free Speech Movement cafe at Cal, with the silent news playing in the background.
author: Stephanie S.

description: Just had this place for the first time. To all you reviewers, eh... I mean yelpers(glad I'm not one of them yet) don't order fish unless you're at a fish restaurant!!! This isn't a fish taco stand in Baja, its an honest Americanized Mexican place with a great setting and very decent food at honest prices. My advice there after 3pm and have their tacos $2 each(carnitas is great), and drink their beer on tap, $3 a pint and do us all a favor, don't order the fish tacos and then complain about it. Comprende?
author: Janie M.

description:
Pretty disappointed w/ our first trip here but we are willing to give it another shot. 

The place itself is very cute (decor wise). The burritos..well they left a lot to be desired. The guy making mine had no idea what he was doing. He wasn't even sure what a whole wheat tortilla was - so he just used plain. The pork was pretty much flavorless and they didn't really seem to know how to correctly wrap the burrito (you'd get a mouthful of one item at a time). The lady preparing my husband's burrito wasn't thrilled when he asked for corn and hot sauce. 

Overall - not great food. BUT we will be optimistic and hope they start adding some flavor to the meat. The place really does look great and we are thrilled to have a burrito place in the neighborhood.
author: Laura B.

description: Meh, $10 for a gut bomb and a soda.  Below average food, super heavy.  Baseball on the two TVs.  Meh.
author: Nik E.

description: This place is exaclty what it should be, for where it is. Busy during the lunch hours, and good amount of traffic, so the food is always fresh. Some healthy options like burrito bowl, etc.. They thought about the little things, like keeping the home-made salsa on ice, some big flat screens up in the corners for enertainment, high open ceilings..its just a good feel.
author: John B.

description: This is the worst place for mexican food ever!!!  The baby burrito I ordered was soo bland... i had to dump salsa all over it to give it any sort of taste!  I was with my friend walking back to her place and I mentioned to her that I was hungry.  She suggested The Iron Cactus because it was across the street but she warned me that the food is not the best.  I thought I'd give it a try... The ordering, paying, and getting my food seemed and was so complicated... and they were SO DAMN SLOW!!  Other taquerias that I go into the city have great systems getting those burritos down the assembly line.  There is no assembly line here what-so-ever!  The place was very slow with not that many patrons.. and the wait for my baby burrito... nearly 20 minutes!!! its like my burrito disappeared for awhile... never ever again will I go to this establishment!  I wonder if the owner ever tried mexican food.. this place needs serious over-haul!
author: Jasen L.

description: My first review tee'd this place up in hopes of nothing but success. What a let down! The neighborhood needed a great Taqueria and Iron Cactus rolled out the red carpet opening in a renovated space which appeared all set to take care of our quality burrito needs that Victors down the street has given up on long ago. Looks are deceiving, because my Iron Cactus report card is that of a high school drop out. You walk in and it just gets ridiculous right off the bat. This isnt a one time gig, I have been here on numerous occasions with different friends and its a joke and I read all these reviews and they are saying the same thing. I say no rice, I get rice, I say black beans, I get pinto. I get pieces of corn and other ingredients that appear to have fallen into my burrito by cross spooning ingredients. Each time I go over the order to be sure its correct, but it doesnt even matter. Then were at the register paying and every time I have been here this has been a deer in the headlights process. They even modeled themselves after Poncho Villa? Excuse me? The same place that pulled a grand opening, grand closing next to the Ferry Building where its impossible to fail because thousands of well educated people with cash walk past your front door? I personally hate Poncho Villa because their burritos are flavorless, um, next on the review, the flavor of Iron Cactus is pathetic. These burritos suck. I have gotten them to go, and its cold by the time I get home just a block away. Please read these reviews and figure it out over there, we all wanted this restaurant to do great, and instead they dont have a clue. This place is a joke!
author: Michael G.

description: Fantastic casual mexican spot. I go for lunch 3-4 times a week. Spicy shrimp salad is awesome (super spicy) and super wet burrito is amazing. There are a lot of mediocre food-line mexican places, but this is not one of them...love IC!
author: JOHN O.

description: Food is fresh, service was good, but tamales carinitas special was uninspired.  Nice selection of beers and a good atmosphere. Just don't expect more than Chevy's quality food. Nice patio if you want to have a drink in the sun...
author: Jon I.

description: Reasonably priced beers, with a little bit of variety. Too bad the Happy Hour deal only applied to Miller Lite (gag) and ended at 6. I'm not complaining too much about $5 Sierra Tumbler though. We didn't get food but it didn't look as bad as some have said here. Solid spot for pre-Giants.
author: Nick Y.

description: not quite mexican, but not quite that bad either. avoid the guacamole (and the price of it too!).  I would give this 3.5 stars instead of three, maybe even 3.75. the 2$ tacos at happy hour are GI-NORMOUS and one could fill u up quite substantially.
author: Nicole H.

description: I want to give ZERO star but it won't let me.  I ordered foods from them several times and yet they always gave me the wrong order.  Is it me that I don't speak Spanglish?  I thought they would understand my English perfectly since I always repeat my order several times to make sure they got it right.  But, NO!  First, second and third time I was like ok..no more going there again...but then I gave it another try...I paid for a side order rice and 2 grilled chicken Taco with fried tortilla instead of soft...brr..I just can't eat the soft ones.  The girl said she got what I ordered, but when I am back at the office....hello!!  No fried torrilla OR my side order!!  They are missing!!  What's going on????  And I paid $5.50 for 2 wrong taco with no sour cream or guacamole?  Ok..this is way too much....in a really BAD way...I can't take it anymore..  I rather spend $12.00 for a healthy Salmon Teriyaki at NAMA instead.  I picked up a phone and complained...the guy who rang me up was defensive instead of apologizing when I explained everything.  Where is the customer service?  What kind of manager who hired all these people who have absolutely ZERO customer service!!???!!???  They just never got anything right!!!  I wouldn't go there anymore, ever!  I rather spend my money elsewhere....I don't care about the price...as long as I got what I order and what I paid for...I won't invest on this place...it's horrible..horrible place....They need staff who speak English .. sorry..but it's just the way it is....not everybody speak Spanish here...OKAY???  This is not Mexico!!
author: Jasmijn L.

description:
i was excited when this place opened because SOMA is totally lacking good cheap mexican food, but i found out that this place offers none of those things.

the ambiance is cool for a casual take out/lunch place, but the food is mediocre and totally overpriced for what it is.  the carnitas was sooo dry that i felt like i was chewing on leather.  maybe if it were half the price i would go back, but i paid $8 for something that had the texture of a dog's chew toy and probably half the flavor.

the strawberry agua frescas was good though.
author: Evelyn C.

description: Fantastic spot for an evening dinner/happy hour event.  I was hosting a group of 30+ alumni this week for a Giants game and needed a place to meet up for drinks and easy apps.  I work in the neighborhood and have been to the Iron Cactus for lunch on several occasions, so I checked to see what they could set up for us.  To our delight, the owner blocked off the entire patio and put a number of signs up in preparation of our arrival (all without having to put up a deposit or guaranteeing X amount of spend).  We ordered a bunch of the Tuesday special $2 Coronas and $1 tacos, which kept coming.  The service was fantastic and the staff made sure we were well taken care of. Great outdoor patio space and the Tuesday special can't be beat.  I'll be back for the Tuesday tacos and beers, anytime I'm headed to the ball park with a group, or anytime I need a solid happy hour event space in Soma.  Thank you guys
author: Ryan H.

description: This place has come a long way. Great quality food and tasty too. I work around here so it was a great welcome to the neighborhood. Staff and management rock!!
author: Jason E.

description: I thought this place was pretty good - I like their burrito bowls and salads. Over all pretty tasty. I came here on their opening day when they were still working out the kinks. They seem to have a good system now. Their happy hour rocks - affordable beer YAY! It's a nice alternative to Tres Agave in the neighborhood - not as expensive or crowded - more on the affordable and casual end. Too bad they don't have tequila there.
author: Christie W.

description: Seems to be a real mixed bag of reviews for the Iron Cactus, here's my addition. If you work in this area, like me, you should very happy to see another lunchtime choice for food, so that's worth a couple of stars right there. I suppose it's been open a couple of months now and should be settled in its operation. I have visited twice and had to forget it once because of the line out the down and down the street. First visit: spicy chicken taco, delicious, in and out fast and surprisingly cheap. Second visit: The guy taking my order could hardly speak English, after three attempts of trying to understand what he was asking me I just shrugged my shoulders and said yes to what ever he was asking me. This time I had a grilled chicken burrito again very tasty and washed down with an ice cold beer. So, so far so good, still working my way through the menu. Decor is great, service friendly and it looks clean. I'll only visit if I can get served quickly which is sadly my normal lunch speed.
author: Kevin S.

description: A pricey taqueria.  i wanted to basically make my own burrito by telling them what i wanted in it since i didnt see the one i wanted on the menu.  they couldnt figure out how to price it and so basically for a no meat burrito it was around 10.00.
author: Julie G.

description:
Food is decent.  

Service - well, this incident caused me to create a yelp account.  Ok, it wasn't THAT bad, but nonetheless.  Go online, print out fax order form.  Fill in order for a chicken quesadilla ($6.50) and fax.  Walk to bank to kill time.  Go into IC, up to register to pay, expecting my food to be ready.  Well, they hadn't checked the fax machine.  He pulls the order, and doesn't ask me any questions about it, but hands it to the lady to make the food.  After a 5 minute wait (fine), she is boxing it up and asks me if I want it regular or super.  I said, I don't know what the difference is...the fax order form didn't specify one way or another, and homeboy didn't ask me when he first looked at it.  I said, regular I guess.  She gets this look like "they are going to dock my paycheck if I have to redo this", meaning she had made a super.  So I say fine, I'll take the super.  And so the cashier/manager charges me for a super!  I roll my eyes, too hungry to argue, and walk out paying $9.30.  

Tips for IC:  
1)  Put your fax machine in a place where your employees can see it.  
2)  Tell your cashier that "it is really busy today" is not that great of an excuse.
3)  Allow your cashier the authority to give me a break (should have charged me for regular) when clearly they had made a mistake.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
My new find.....
First, let's say that the place is immaculate, not to mention so forward in using reclaimed & recycled  materials in their decor/structure. Bravo!!!
Second, the staff is fantastic. They are friendly & super helpful in a genuine authentic way. They are not just patronizing for business sake. This also includes the guys & gals who work in the Creamery next door. I frequently venture over with lil ones just exploring & finding their way in the world, but never have received that "oh, no, here comes the kiddies-quick hide the..." sigh & eyeroll that is way to commonplace in this world. Now, I understand some children aren't as well behaved, but to assume that they will be a nightmare to deal with is just plain unfair. The staff here are always smiling & waving back & treat all there guests as just that. 
Third, DELICIOUS! FRESH! QUALITY! cuisine. YOu know how rare that is? Peppers that taste like peppers, not the oil or grease or lard some people use to stretch dollar. Fajitas with black beans, great salsa verde, & a happy hour beer? What better way to head out to the ballpark? 
Fourth, actually outdoor seating areas that have sunlight!!! 
Fifth, gracious owners. On more than one occasion I have had the pleasure to meet both. They remember my name, the lil ones, my favorite items, & take a true interest in getting to know their patrons & what we might be needing to improve our experience. 
Now to all you yuppie comment making people...why not be a little more judgmental in your life? Labels are for clothing & food products, not people. To label this place as a yuppie hangout could not be furthest from the truth. I have seen families, business folks, nannies, mommies, students & HARD WORKING people who much like the most of us are hoping to get the best value for our dollars. 
To each their own, but for me, I am thrilled to have found the Iron Cactus & the Creamery, too!
Now, just be sure to save me a seat.....
author: N J.

description: The food is good and the price is fair. I get the tofu burrito. The food I don't feel is anything special. I will stop by to pick something up for dinner on my way home from work occasionally. The food is pretty fresh, and feels healthy. There are happy hour specials lthat ook really good.
author: raj g.

description: I, too, loathe Victor's and Chavo's and was super excited to see The Iron Cactus open shop. The space is cool, and the burritos are actually better than the aforementioned places'. However, The Iron Cactus is super uncool to charge the same amount for burritos with without meat as for burritos with meat. That's $5.90 for a "baby burrito" (rice, beans, salsa; cheese is extra). Third Street Grill made this mistake when it first opened, too, but it has since added a veggie burrito option with lower pricing. Also, service at The Iron Cactus is super slow and inefficient -- maybe they should take some tips from Mexico Au Parc (which I am also not too keen on but which I do not loathe) to see how to cycle people through?
author: Midori S.

description: I want to like this place because I work so close and the man who I think is the owner seems like a nice guy. The restaurant is bright and sunny and they have outdoor seating. All awesome and very inviting. The food isn't the most exciting but unlike some places I do find the quality of their meat to be good. Despite this the negative feeling I get while standing in this place waiting endlessly for my order is too powerful. The staff is difficult to understand and very, very short on the phone. The first time I ordered I placed my order online - love that convenience. But when I showed up at the time the instructions told me to arrive, they were completely clueless. Not only did they not have my order ready, the two people at the front had no idea what I was talking about when I said I ordered online. The manager came out and said "oh, I didn't know that was active!" Duh. They then took 30 minutes to make my food. They finally offered me a drink for waiting. I get this place is busy during lunch time but it's no excuse for the lack of eye contact, rude staff, and idle chit chat while the place is packed.
author: Angela M.

description: I went here today for lunch.I was there last week and it was crazy busy .I preferred it today with less people.I liked it a lot.It didn't look like the typical Taqueria.I am a bit of an interior snob.It has a beautiful old wood ceiling and a concrete floor.I  liked the feel of the place.It was raining pretty hard outside so I didn't have to wait in line.I just ordered a chicken burrito with black beans, not very adventuress I know .I saw they had beers on tape so I ordered a Fat Tire (It was a Friday ) .It is not easy to find a place that does good fast Mexican food around 4th & Brannan.The service was fast and the staff really friendly.It only opened a few weeks ago but I would definitely go back. It is connected to The Creamery coffee shop so I just walked in there and got a double shot of espresso to get through Friday afternoon.
author: Mark L.

description: I've been passing by this place and watching it get renovated and was impressed with what they were doing with the place...it look like a casual dining place. I figured "yay! something new a block from home". Well, it finally opened up, and I find out it's not really a casual sit down dinner place, but a slightly polished Taqueria. LOL. I walked in because I was curious, and because they have a $2 tacos and beer happy hour special. Service was quick, and cafeteria style. The food was constantly being replaced and made fresh. The price was right, and the service was great. The owner came out and talked to me for a bit.  For having just opened up , this place isn't bad. The steak tacos were perfect and well seasoned. The servings were generous and I was happy to have something this close. The only reason I'm giving it 3 stars instead of 4 is because my chicken was dry. I can see this being a quick and easy happy hour place when I get back from work. They also have a nice patio which is a plus. All in all I'll have to go back and try this place again...make sure that they can do something outside of steak tacos well.
author: Rene A.

description: Bland food, bad service.  Nice interior.
author: B P.

description: I've been here twice.  The first time it was decent enough to give a second chance.  The second time I got two carnitas tacos with rice and beans, which I consider a you better not mess up on mexican order.  One of the two tacos was entirely pork fat.  Not acceptable, regardless of how expensive or inexpensive you should not pay for a taco full of fat.
author: Adam J.

description: I have been here three times since they opened. Every time it gets worse and worse. Two of the three times, they mixed up my order. In general, the food is over salted and under seasoned. The nachos have very little cheese. The meat in the burritos and the soup are too salty and lack flavor. The spicy option is hardly noticeable and the salsa is watery. On the plus side, the people are friendly and they offer beer and wine. In a pinch, I would head to panera instead. If you have more time, I would go to Tres Agaves.
author: MIcah S.

description:
Ok, I will give it a chance.
But before I go back, I want the cooks to go to Chipotle and learn how to cook rice.
The rice is miserable.  Esp since that is 90 % of the burrito they stuff in there.
The steak is msg ridden with no beef flavor.
The salsa? omg, it is sooo bland.  
The mexican people who work there are not happy to have a job.  They are smiling thru their angry teeth, is it that bad to work there???
I agree, I want to have a good burrito place around here but this is just ridiculous, i would rather have a taco bell than this piece of trash.  The place is also wayy too cold.  maybe i'll go for a beer but food? i don't think so.  this place has the personality of the ridiculous coffee shop next door.  
I can only say that i am glad there aren't too many people who go there since i don't want to run into a crowd of non food knowing people when i take my daily walk.
I can say that i will let my dog do his business around this place tho.
Why so upset? Cuz i love my california burritos and i can't believe  they must have money to burn.
I will visit again in 8 days.  if it does not change, the rice, the salsa, 
and whatnot i will be peessed. btw, they didn't even put salsa in my burrito.  i had to ask for chips and salsa, omg!
author: Sophia M.

description: Really good meal, don't understand why so many on here are expecting a high-end meal? It's mexican food.... the tostada salad with prawns was awesome, and with drink, only $15 with the tip!
author: Dante D.
